subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: Surface case distributions reflect an intricately interrelated system of semantic roles, grammatical relations, and language-particular case marking systems. A historical review of the development of research in this area in the generative theoretical framework reveals an illuminating process of integration and disintegration.

Research on case has a long history covering a variety of surface phenomena involving morphology, syntax, and semantics. It is rather curious that in the generative tradition case had not been a central research topic until the emergence of Government and Binding Theory (henceforth abbreviated as GB) in the early part of the 1980s, which proposed Case Theory, a theory of abstract case (often termed ‘Case’), closely tied to Theta Theory. 1 These theories are part of the subsystems of principles proposed by GB. The reason for the non-central role that research on case played in this era lies partly in the assumption of Standard Theory (ST) that grammatical relations, subject, object, and so on, are derivatively determined by syntactic structures and that structurally determined grammatical relations determine grammatical functions of noun phrases. 2

In this general theoretical trend, research on case played a central role in Japanese grammars supporting the transformational approach to syntax. For example, the hypothesis of ST of the cyclic application of transformations was supported by Japanese case marking transformations, and the adequacy of assumptions of sentential complementation and Equi-NP deletion was attested by the derivation of Japanese complex predicates like causative and passive verb complexes.

The purpose of this chapter is, in the first place, to show the main issues involved in research on case in Japanese, which have contributed to the formation of a series of new theories up to the Minimalist Program (henceforth abbreviated as MP). Second, this chapter attempts to contribute to the refinement of the MP by revealing the syntactic mechanism employed in the construction of Japanese major syntactic structures, in which structural and inherent case particles play significant roles.

This chapter contains reviews of major generative works on case in Japanese during the past 35 years. Sections 2 through 5 review how research on the Japanese case system developed within the frameworks of ST and Extended Standard Theory (EST) with their basic tenet of structural determination of case. It is shown that during this period of transformational pursuits, most of the relevant facts were discovered, and these facts have been used as crucial data and recast over and over again in new frameworks as theoretical changes evolved. Gruber's prelexical transformation and Fillmore's ‘Case grammar’ are outlined because they have played important roles in the development of a syntactic theory of case. Section 5 brings up technical improvements made in the transformational approach during the 1980s within the framework of GB, later called the Principles and Parameters Approach (PPA). In this period, case in various typologically different languages was studied extensively from the point of view of Universal Grammar. Marantz (1984) and Baker (1988a) are representative of these studies. Unfortunately, their works are not included in this review because our main task is elucidating the results of research on Japanese case.

Section 6 presents an outline of case checking theory, a fast developing theory within the framework of MP. It is shown that as far as Japanese is concerned the descriptive data coverage of the works examined in this section is almost the same as previous works, only with a few additions of novel data. Their merits seem to be basically the effort to deal with case variations among many languages in the framework with minimum mechanical tools. To the extent they are successful, they achieve the goal of filling out Universal Grammar. This section is included despite the fact that the section itself is unduly brief and schematic due to its fast changing nature, because it is necessary to see the actual working of MP in dealing with the Japanese case phenomena.

Now let us point out some specific features of representative works reviewed in this chapter. The first stage in the 1960s emerged as a reaction to the thesis of ST, which claimed that semantic interpretation of a sentence is based solely on deep structure. Gruber (1965) proposed that prelexical structures in which semantic roles, represented by abstract prepositions like FROM, TO, and so on, are subject to prelexical transformations, which depend on the specification carried by each verb as to which role can be the subject. On the other hand, Fillmore (1968), for example, proposed that semantic roles, labeled as AGENT, PATIENT, GOAL, and the like called case (C) are syntactic primitives and a transformation called ‘subjectivization’ moves the highest case in the case hierarchy to the surface subject position. Both of these approaches are based on an awareness of the fact that semantic roles and grammatical relations do not maintain one-to-one correspondences. The important aspect of these claims is that they are sensitive to the case alternations observed in pairs of sentences with verbs like sell and those like buy, and some other sentence relations of this type. In this point of view, there is no basic line of demarcation between structural cases and inherent cases (or semantic cases) marked by postpositions in Japanese grammars. Section 3 gives details of their proposals.

Kuroda (1965) emphasized the distinction between structural and inherent cases and made a proposal for cyclic linear case marking transformations for the structural cases. Inherent case particles, called postpositions, did not attract attention from generative researchers at that time. Kuno (1973c) is an extension of Kuroda (1965). Details of these analyses are given in section 4.

Kuroda's transformational approach was followed persistently through the 1960s, 1970s, and to the middle of the 1980s, with minor modifications or refinements. All these grammars tried to relate grammatical relations to surface case alignments, disregarding the semantic roles noun phrases bear. Section 5 deals with modifications and attempts to refine Kuroda (1965, 1978) and Kuno (1973c).

With the appearance of GB, case theory and theta theory were highlighted as core principles of syntax. In its later development as the PPA in the middle of the 1980s, its case theory, enforcing case checking in terms of agreement, aroused lively discussions. One is Kuroda's proposal for the parameter of forced vs. non-forced agreement, discussed at the end of section 5.

Marantz (1992) also called into question the validity of case checking in the PPA, making an alternative proposal for the case realization rules, which are discussed in section 6, together with an application of some of his rules to Japanese by Aoyagi.

These and other works along this line of argumentation against case theory have motivated a good deal of research on case in Japanese in the Minimalist framework. Watanabe (1996), Koizumi (1998), Ura (1996, 1999, 2000, 2001), and Fukui and Takano (1998) are reviewed in section 6 as representatives of these works.

subsection.heading: 2 Semantic roles, grammatical relations, and case marking (case realization)
subsection.p: The term ‘case’ has been used ambiguously at least in the following three ways: one standing for ‘theta-roles’ in the recent framework of generative grammar, the second used in place of grammatical relations such as ‘subject’, ‘object’, and ‘indirect object’, and the third as the actual case realization such as ga (nominative), o (accusative), and ni (dative) in Japanese.

The ambiguous uses do not necessarily mean that there has been little awareness of the fact that there are not always one-to-one correspondences among these three types of case. It is closer to the truth to say that due to this awareness the linguists working on this problem have investigated how some semantic roles come to be identified with grammatical relations. Gruber (1965) and Fillmore (1968, 1971b, 1973, 1977) represent this approach. These works made a tremendous contribution to the theory of case by showing that well-formed syntactic structures are guaranteed mostly by lexical information carried by predicates (usually verbs and adjectives) as to the number of co-occurring obligatory noun phrases and semantic roles they bear. Information of this kind has later been formalized as argument structures of predicates (Grimshaw 1990, for example). In the framework of the PPA, ‘theta-positions’ play a crucial role in guaranteeing well-formed syntactic structures.

The study of case in Japanese in the generative framework started with the investigation of the Japanese case marking mechanism on the basis of grammatical relations, assuming the distinction between structural case markers, ga, o, (ni), 3 and semantic case markers (conventionally called postpositions) such as de (locative: ‘at’ or ‘in’, or instrumental: ‘with’), kara (ablative: ‘from’), and to (commitative: ‘with’). Since changes of grammatical relations lead to changes in distribution of structural case particles, the study of case in this sense has developed hand in hand with the study of major Japanese syntactic structures such as causatives, passives, desiderative sentences, and so on, whose derivations involve changes in grammatical relations. As a result it has been revealed that there is a considerable discrepancy between grammatical relations and the distribution of structural case particles. For example, nominative ga does not necessarily mark the subject, the particle o is the surface realization of both the structural accusative case and the semantic role ‘path’, and the ni of so-called ‘double object constructions’ is treated as a structural case by a group of linguists, while it is a postposition according to another group. Moreover, ni appears as a postposition denoting ‘location’.

Traditional Japanese linguists regard all noun phrases with case particles as modifiers of predicates. This school has never given special status to the subject, nor has it recognized the unique syntactic functions of the subject. One of the influential Japanese linguists Akira Mikami (1953, among other works by the same author) reacted against the use of the notion of subject in some Japanese grammars, claiming that the notion is not relevant to the Japanese language but was simply borrowed from grammars of European languages where subject–verb (in the generative framework subject–auxiliary) agreement is observed. In contrast to this opinion, Shibatani (1978) argues that the notion of subject and the nominative ga as a marker of subject should be distinguished, pointing out the functions of the subject as the trigger of subject-orientated honorification, which is independent of ga marking, as is shown by the sentences in (1), and its function as the antecedent of the reflexive form zibun (‘self’), as in (2):

‘Mr Kato can use a computer.’

On top of the emphasis on distinct status given to the subject by generative grammarians, the nominative and accusative agreements have been given an important role of licensing argument noun phrases since the inception of the PPA. In view of the fact that Japanese does not show case agreement, it is very natural that various recent works on Japanese syntax claim licensing mechanisms other than agreement. The details of this new direction in the study of case will be given in section 5.

subsection.heading: 3 Semantic roles in relation to grammatical relations
subsection.p: In this section, a review will be given of two representative works that emphasize the semantic roles noun phrases bear as the basis of grammatical relations, ‘subject’ and ‘object’. There was keen awareness underlying all of these works that the interpretation of a sentence cannot be determined solely by deep structure, as assumed by ST.

When the prelexical transformation moves [PP[Prep FROM] NP] to the sentence initial position replacing [Theme NP] followed by incorporation of FROM into the verb, the prelexical structure (5a) is derived, into which verbs like sell are inserted (as in (4b)), while the replacement of the theme with [PP[Prep TO] NP] results in the prelexical structure (5b) which permits the insertion of verbs like buy (as in (4c)). (The incorporation of the preposition is indicated by + in (5).)
Verbs like sell, lend, give, and so on have the specification (6a) as the frame for their insertion into deep structures, while those like buy, borrow, obtain, and so forth are with (6b):

Thus, Gruber is the first to explicitly point out the discrepancy between semantic roles and grammatical relations. The important facts accounted for by this grammar are that the subject bears various semantic roles such as source (FROM in Gruber), Goal (TO), and theme and that theme can both be a subject and an object in syntactic structures. The incorporation of prepositions into verbs fits well in the syntax of languages in which the subject and the object appear without any case marking. For languages with overt case marking on every noun phrase, this grammatical model apparently does not seem appropriate. However, it is undeniable that Kuroda's (1965) hypothesis (to be summarized in section 4) of unmarked noun phrases, standing for structural case bearers, shares the same insight with Gruber. Gruber's term ‘theme’ is employed by the later generative grammars in their technical terms ‘thematic structure’, ‘theta-role’, ‘theta position’, and so on.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Fillmore: ‘Case grammar’
subsection.p: Fillmore (1968) claims that a structure deeper (or more abstract) than the deep structure as conceived of by ST is necessary for adequate interpretation of a sentence. According to him the primitives of syntactic structure must be ‘cases’ (or semantic roles) such as agent, patient, source, goal, and so on, which are introduced by the base rules in (7):

(7)
a. S xrArr M + P
b. P xrArr V + C1 + . . . + Cn
c. C xrArr K + NP

In (7) M stands for modals including negation, tense, mood, and aspect. P stands for proposition consisting of a verb and any number of Cs (Cases), K for any types of case markers, prepositions, postpositions, inflection, and so on, C (Case) for A(gentive), D(ative), O(bjective), I(nstrumental), L(ocative), and the like. The rules in (7) generate structures like the following:
Each verb carries the specification for the case frame (like (9)) that it can be inserted into:
Take the verb open for example. It has the specification (10), which can be realized as the structures (11a–d):

In Case grammar, the subject is derived by a transformation called ‘subjectivization’, which chooses as a subject the highest C in the case hierarchy, which goes as follows: agent, experiencer, instrument, object, source, goal, location, time (Fillmore 1971b).
The deep structures (11a–d) are realized as (11′a–d) by ‘subjectivization’:

(11′)
a. John opened the door with this key.
b. This key opened the door.
c. John opened the door.
d. The door opened.

The distribution of Cs is constrained by the condition that “P must be thought of as a list of formulas of the form seen in (11) [(7b) above] where at least one case category must be chosen and where the same case category never appears more than once” (Fillmore 1968: 24). This condition was adopted by the PPA as the Theta Criterion, with the addition of a clause that each noun phrase must have only one theta-role.

Fillmore shares with Gruber the idea that deep structure assumed by ST does not give sufficient information for the interpretation of sentences. Both of them contributed to the advancement of generative theory by showing the importance of semantic roles, which have a function distinct from grammatical relations of showing lexical relations of transitive and intransitive verbs, relations of sentences with source or goal for subjects, and similar structural relations. Fillmore went a step ahead by making claims for Universal Grammar, in particular claims for the condition of “only one instance of each case in a simple sentence” and “subjectivization.” His ‘K’, standing for all sorts of case markers, makes it easier to use the Case Grammar for analysis of languages with various types of case marking systems. For example, some Japanese linguists, especially those working on machine translation, found Case grammar most adequate to the description of Japanese syntactic structures, mainly because Japanese noun phrases, both arguments and adjuncts, are followed by case particles and because the Japanese subject does not have the same syntactic roles as the subject in languages like English.
With the works represented by Gruber and Fillmore, semantic roles, grammatical relations, and actual case marking started to be integrated into a modular system of grammar.

subsection.heading: 4 Transformational analyses of case in Japanese
subsection.p: In this section, systems of transformational case marking (or assignment) are reviewed, covering works ranging from Kuroda (1965) up to those based on the PPA in the 1980s.

Kuroda's seminal work (1965) laid the foundation for the transformational analysis of case in Japanese generative grammar. For more than 15 years, the basic tenet of his work was retained with only minor modifications. Kuroda himself summarizes his study along the line of this work in 1978, which will be reviewed in this section together with important modifications and additions by other linguists, working in the framework of EST in the 1970s and the PPA in the 1980s.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Structural cases vs. postpositions (unmarked vs. marked NPs in deep structure)
subsection.p: Kuroda (1965) proposed to introduce certain NPs without case particles into deep structures. Those NPs are called unmarked NPs, which are ready to get structural cases ga and o by case marking transformations. All the other NPs are introduced into deep structures already marked with postpostions. At the time of its appearance, the idea of distinguishing structural case particles from postpositions was in sharp contrast with the idea of introducing NPs marked by case particles (both structural case particles and postpositions) into the base. These particles were assumed to subcategorize verbs and adjectives (Inoue 1964, 1969, for example). Kuroda's concentration on the study of structural cases laid the foundation for research on the Japanese case system. This idea is maintained basically even in works under the MP.
The salient feature of Kuroda's approach is the cyclic assignment of ga and o according to the linear order of unmarked NPs. Let us call this approach linear cyclic case marking.

The ideas of unmarked NPs and transformational case marking were challenged by lexicalist approaches in the late 1970s and the early 1980s. However, the idea of linear case marking itself had never been called in question until the emergence of recent works based on the PPA and the MP. The recent development in the framework of MP will be outlined in section 6.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Structural case marking dependent on transformational derivation of complex predicates
subsection.p: Beyond simple sentence structures, namely, transitive and intransitive sentences with root predicates, Japanese major sentence structures involve suffixation of bound forms with syntactic properties and semantic contents, such as the causative (s)ase, passive (r)are, 6 potential (r)e or (r)are, desiderative ta(k), and so on. Furthermore, it is possible to chain them together as, for example, root-sase-rare-tak (‘want to be caused to root’), deriving complex predicates. Under this circumstance it seems natural to assume lexical derivation of complex predicates disregarding syntactic changes caused by such derivational processes. However, this alternative has a serious drawback because it is impossible to show the case particle alternations caused by affixation of this sort by simply analyzing internal structures of predicates.

subsection.heading: 4.2.1 Sentential complementation
subsection.p: The transformational approach assumes, in the first place, that the predicative affixes such as (s)ase (causative), (r)are (passive), (r)e, (r)are, (potential), ta(k) (desiderative), and so on are independent predicates requiring sentential complementation. (21b) is a rough sketch of the sentential complement structure of o-causative (12a), repeated below as (21a) (Kuno 1978b):

(21)
a. Taroo ga Hanako o hatarak-ase-ta.
Taroo Nom Hanako Acc work-Caus-Past
‘Taro made Hanako work.’
b.

The fact that in Japanese only the subject can be the antecedent of the reflexive form zibun was used as evidence for the assumption of sentential complement structures for complex predicates. Take (22) for example, both Taro and Hanako can be interpreted as the antecedents of zibun:
(22) [Tarooi ga Hanakoj o [Hanakoj ga zibuni/j no heya de hatarak] aseta]
Unless Hanakoj is assumed to be present as the complement subject in deep structure, as indicated by (21b), its function as the antecedent of zibun cannot be accounted for.

As a corollary to the assumption of sentential complement structures for complex predicates, case marking is assumed to apply cyclically to this structure. This assumption, originated by Kuroda (1965) and shared by the linguists supporting transformational case marking (Kuno 1973c; Inoue 1976; Kuroda 1978; Tonoike 1978, among others), reflects the insight that both simple and complex predicates require the same basic case alignments, namely, ga, ga-o, (ga-ni-o). 10

subsection.heading: 4.2.2 Cyclicity, verb raising, and Equi-NP deletion
subsection.p: Cyclic case marking and verb raising have been employed in all transformational case marking systems, with differences only in the treatment of the particle ni and Equi-NP Deletion. As for the analysis of major sentence structures, there have been various different proposals. Kuroda (1965) is based on ST. With the basic ideas of Kuroda (1965) intact, Kuroda (1978) extended its coverage of data, taking into consideration various claims and proposals made through the 1960s and 1970s, among which the most influential were Kuno (1973c) and Harada (1973). To discuss the whole range of structural case particle distribution, Kuroda (1978) is summarized as the point of departure, followed by alternative proposals relevant to case marking.

Despite all the original contributions to the theory of case marking in Japanese, Kuroda's system has certain limitations. One limitation is given here, because it is a keystone of the whole system. That is his admission of only ga and o as structural cases, as shown by (23), excluding all kinds of ni as postpositions, which results in an inability to account for the fact that an indirect object is readily passivized, as shown by the passive counterpart of (13), given below as (24).
(23) Mark the first unmarked noun phrase with ga, and mark any other unmarked noun phrase or phrases with o.

(24)
Taroo ga titioya ni taikin o watas-are-ta.
Taroo Nom father by a lot of money Acc give-Pass-Past
‘Taro was given a lot of money by his father.’
Applied to a simple transitive sentence, (23) derives the standard ga-o (Nom-Acc) case array of simple transitive sentences.
With this much overview, let us proceed with the discussion of Kuroda's case marking system.

Taking (21b) as an example let us see how (23) is applied. First Hanako in the complement sentence gets ga marked, since it is the first unmarked NP on this cycle. There is no other unmarked NP in the complement sentence, so we proceed to the second cycle, deleting the already case-marked NP Hanako by Equi-NP deletion on the basis of its coreferentiality with the object NP Hanako in the matrix sentence. (For the analysis of o-causative without the matrix object (Inoue 1976; Tonoike 1978), Equi-NP deletion is inapplicable.) Next the complement predicate hatarak- (‘work’) is raised and adjoined to the matrix predicate (s)ase deriving the complex predicate hatarak-ase (‘cause to work’). Since the complement sentence loses its subject and predicate by Equi NP deletion and Verb Raising respectively, the complement S node is deleted, resulting in the structure in (25):

To this structure rule (23) applies again. Since Taroo is the first unmarked noun phrase it gets ga marked, and Hanako, the other unmarked noun phrase, gets o marked on it. Thus, case marking proceeds cyclically based on the linear order of unmarked NPs. This is how (23) derives the case alignment of transitive sentences both simple and complex.

subsection.heading: 4.2.3 Subject ni-raising and counter Equi-NP deletion
subsection.p: To account for the other type of causative, namely Ni-causative, Kuroda introduces a transformational rule called subject ni-raising, “which makes the embedded subject a clause mate of the matrix verb and assigns it the particle ni” 11 (Kuroda 1978: 30).
The Ni-causative such as (12b), given below as (26a), is assumed to have the structure in (26b):

(26)
a. Taroo ga Hanako ni hatarak-ase-ta.
‘Taro let Hanako work.’
b.

Note that there is no extra NP in the matrix of this sentence. In the first cycle the first unmarked NP Hanako gets ga marked on it, followed by subject ni-raising and verb raising. Due to subject ni-raising, the complement subject Hanako receives ni on top of ga, resulting in Hanako ga ni. Since a noun phrase with ga or o is regarded as unmarked, doubling of structural cases as in Hanako ga ni is an inevitable consequence of cyclic case marking, so the deletion of the first case particle from such a sequence of structural case particles becomes obligatory. (This rule is formalized by Kuno (1973c: 335) as ga/o Deletion, which reads: Delete ga and o if they are followed by some other particle.) After the embedded S node is deleted the sentence has the following structure:

Since Hanako is already marked with ni, Taroo is the first and only unmarked NP which receives ga by Rule (23). Thus, (A) sentence types, i.e. both o- and ni-causatives, are derived with the two additional rules, subject ni-raising and ga/o Deletion. This much has been widely accepted through the 1970s and the early part of the 1980s.

Subject ni-raising is employed extensively by Kuroda, in the derivation of the (A) ni-causative as given above, (C) indirect passive (14c), (E) ni-ga potential (16b), and (I) o-causative with a transitive complement sentence (20), most of them different in syntactic properties. ‘Mr Kato made the child carry the baggage.’ (o-causative with a transitive complement sentence)
The complement sentences for those in (28) are (29a–c):

(29)
a. Otooto ga zyuuyoo syorui o yon-da.
‘His brother read the important document.’
b. Katoo-san ga konna muzukasii zi o yom-u.
‘Mr Kato reads such difficult characters.’
c. Kodomo ga nimotu o hakon-da.
‘The child carried the baggage.’

The indirect passive such as (28a) has a structure similar to that of ni-causatives like (26a), the only difference being in the matrix predicate selection, namely, the selection of the passive -are- instead of the causative -ase-. The derivation proceeds exactly the same way as that of ni-causative.

For the analysis of direct passives, there have emerged two significant proposals, the uniform and non-uniform theories. The former proposes the same deep structure with a complement sentence for both direct and indirect passives. The latter proposes a derivation of direct passives distinct from that of indirect passives. (See Howard and Howard 1976 for details.) An early example is Kuno's (1973c) derivation of direct passives from their active counterparts. 12 The non-uniform analysis in the EST framework like Kuno (1973c) proposes a deep structure similar to that for English passives, as shown by (30):

(30)
a. ___ be Verb-en NP (by NP) (English)
b. ___ (NP ni) NP Verb-rare (Japanese)

Both of these deep structures involve an empty subject position, which is filled by the moved object NP. In Kuno (1973c) the movement of the object NP precedes the case marking transformation, thus preventing the accusative case marking from applying to the object NP. In the subject position the object NP gets ga marked by subject ga marking. In the PPA, a rationale is given to object NP movement, roughly as motivated by the passive morpheme absorbing abstract case assigning ability from the transitive predicate it is attached to and suppressing the theta-role assigned by the predicate to the empty subject position. Thus, the object is left caseless, and its movement to the subject position is obligatory due to the case filter requiring that every lexical NP must have case assigned to it. Because of the subject theta-role suppression, the object NP carries on the theta-role assigned by the verb without violating the theta criterion, which requires only one theta-role for each NP. This basic tenet of passive derivation remains the same regardless of the changes of the case system through the development of generative theory.

Going back to Subject ni-Raising, which assigns ni to complement subjects, the use of this rule for the derivations of ni-causative and indirect passive has enjoyed acceptance, but the same does not hold with the use of this rule for potentials like (28b, c).
The base structure of a potential was assumed to be something like (31):
(31) [Katoo-san [Katoo-san konna muzukasii zi yom]e]ru

Applying rule (23) on the first cycle, we get [Katoo-san ga konna muzukasii zi o yom]. Equi-NP deletion and verb-raising derives [Katoo-san konna muzukasii zi o yom-e-ru]. To this structure (23) applies again, deriving (16a), repeated below as (32):

(32)
Katoo-san ga konna muzukasii zi o yom-e-ru.
Katoo Nom
Acc

Ni-ga potential sentences ((16b) = (28b) for example) pose a problem for Kuroda's system. To derive (28b) from (31), Kuroda has to resort to a nonstandard device, namely Counter Equi deletion, “a deletion rule that wipes out the copy of a noun phrase in the matrix clause under the control of the coreferential copy of the same noun phrase” (Kuroda 1978: 30). Here lies a theoretical problem, since this device is hardly legitimate under the present framework of generative grammar, because the structures derived by Equi-NP deletion were reanalyzed in EST as structures with PRO occupying the complement subject position. Application of Counter Equi results in a structure with PRO in the matrix subject position of (31) governed by the matrix I(nflection). This is counter to the PRO theorem, which requires that PRO be ungoverned. In Kuroda (1978) after Counter Equi wipes out the matrix subject, the complement subject is marked by ni and raised to the matrix clause. Since ni is treated as a postposition, and the complement subject is marked with a postposition, the first unmarked NP is konna muzukasii zi (‘such difficult characters’), which is to be marked with ga. Thus (28b) is derivable in this system only by positing Counter Equi.

Even though the Ni-ga Potential case alignment is accounted for by this device, there are a few empirical problems. First, simple sentences of the (D) type, for example (15a), given below as (33a), can have the same case array. (33b) is an additional example:

(33)
a. watasi-tati ni mondai no honsitu ga yoku wakar- u koto
we Dat problem Gen real nature Nom well understand-Pres that
‘that we can understand well the real nature of the problem.’
b. kono gakusei ni konpyuuta ga deki- ru koto.
this student Dat computor Nom can do-Pres that
‘that this student can use computers.’
In Kuroda's system, simple predicates like wakar (‘understand’) and deki (‘can do’) have to be analyzed as complex predicates involving a sentential complement structure.

The second empirical problem is the inability of this system to account for the ga-ga potential ((16c) for example, repeated below as (34)), since the object ga marking is dependent on the dative subject derived by subject ni-raising:

(34)
Katoo-san ga konna mutukasii zi ga yom-e-ru.
Nom
Nom
Due to the same reason, Kuroda (1978) is unable to derive (G) multiple nominative construction.

Counter Equi is also used by Kuroda to derive (28c), o-causative with a transitive complement, whose deep structure is assumed to be (35). In the first cycle of (35), kodomo (‘child’) and nimotu (‘baggage’) are assigned ga and o respectively. In the second cycle Counter Equi is applied deleting the matrix object kodomo. The complement subject gets ni and is raised to the matrix:

(35)
[Katoo-san kodomo [kodomo nimotu hakob] ase-ta]
‘Mr Kato made his child carry the baggage.’

Putting this analysis in the EST framework, we have the deleted matrix object (kodomo) in (35) appear as PRO, governed by the matrix verb -ase. Thus, neither the PRO in (28b) nor that in (28c) is legitimate in EST and its followers.

If Equi-NP deletion is applied after ga and o marking to the complement subject and object, the complement subject kodomo ga is deleted and the case marking rule (23) is applied in the second cycle, resulting in (36):

(36)
*Katoo-san ga kodomo o nimotu o hakob-ase-ta. (= (I) – (20b))
Nom
Acc
Acc

This sentence is ungrammatical due to the so-called Double O Constraint, originally proposed by Harada (1973). This is a problem for those following EST and subsequent theories along this line. One of the solutions by Kuno is given in the following section.

Finally Kuroda proposes the templates called ‘canonical sentence patterns’, which apply at the end of each cycle. These templates are necessary because he assumes that both Equi and Counter Equi-NP deletion are applied freely. The free application of these rules leads to overgeneration, which requires some filters to screen out ungrammatical case alignments.

(37)
Canonical sentence patterns:
I Transitive sentence pattern: NP ga NP o
II Ergative sentence pattern: NP ni NP ga
III Intransitive sentence pattern: NP ga

Since Counter Equi-NP deletion is not permitted in the present framework, the templates (37), applied cyclically, have ceased to function in the intended way. Moreover, the surface filter makes cyclic transformational case marking redundant, since the filter admits only correct forms regardless of what kind of derivational processes have been followed.

The redundancy of cyclic transformational case marking was noted by lexicalist approaches, such as those proposed by Miyagawa (1980), Ostler (1980), Farmer (1980), and Inoue (1982a, 1982b), which worked out mechanisms for surface case marking.

However, surface templates of this type may be necessary anyway. (See for example Inoue 1997a for discussion of the Double O Constraint as a surface phenomenon.) There is also an important claim made by (37), namely the requirement that every sentence must have one Nominative NP. (Minimum One Nominative Requirement (Inoue (1998).) This requirement was called into question by Inoue (1998), in the face of sentences with subjects marked with postpositions like kara (‘from’) and de (‘with’), rather than ga.

Kuroda's original contributions to the theory of case can be summarized as follows: (i) the distinction between structural and inherent cases in terms of unmarked and marked NPs; (ii) the cyclic transformational case marking by which structural case alternations among ga, o, and ni are captured on the basis of syntactic derivation of complex predicates; (iii) the formulation of case marking rules as general as possible, avoiding the use of specific rules to deal with distributional facts.

Shortcomings of Kuroda's work on case in Japanese are amply revealed in (i) his proposals for Counter Equi-NP deletion, deriving the ni-ga potential as well as avoiding the Double O Constraint; (ii) the failure in accounting for multiple nominative constructions including the ga-ga potential; (iii) the inability to account for the occurrences of the ni-ga case alignment in sentences without sentential complements; (iv) the inability to account for the structural function of the indirect object, as exemplified by (24); (v) the proposal for canonical sentence patterns applying at the end of every cycle, invalidating his own cyclic case marking system.

subsection.heading: 4.3 Structural cases and grammatical relations ‘subject’, ‘object’, and ‘indirect object’
subsection.p: Kuno (1973c) proposed a modification and extension of Kuroda (1965). His case marking system uses the notion of grammatical relations, as those in (38), in sharp contrast with Kuroda's linear case marking. Since grammatical relations are identified by syntactic structures, namely, the subject is defined as the NP immediately dominated by S, and the object as the one immediately dominated by VP, Kuno's case marking appears to be configurational. However, syntactic configuration is not crucially used in Kuno's system, as is clear from (38):

(38)
a. Indirect object marking: Attach ni to the second of three unmarked NPs, that is, to the NPs that do not yet have a particle.
b. Subject marking: Attach ga to the subject NP.
c. Object marking: Attach o to the first nonsubject unmarked NP to the left of the main verb if it is [−stative], and ga if it is [+stative].
(Kuno 1973c: 330)

Employing Equi-NP deletion, Kuno has (38b, c) for marking both the subject and the object of potentials like (16c) with ga in the second cycle, deriving the ga-ga case alignment, thus overcoming Kuroda's limitation (ii). Since (38b, c) apply to sentences with simple stative predicates as well, the ga-ga case array, as in (15c), is also derivable. This saves Kuno's system from Kuroda's limitation (ii). As Object ga marking of stative predicates (38c) is optional in case the object is already marked with o, the ga-o potential case alignment (as in (16a) is derivable. Kuno avoids using Counter Equi and subject ni-raising to derive ni-ga combinations, but uses the surface case alternation rule deriving the surface ni-ga sequence from the ga-ga case alignment (Kuno's ga/ni conversion). The problem with this device will be taken up in section 4.4 in relation to Saito's (1982) analysis.

In Kuroda's system the ni that marks the indirect object is a postposition rather than a structural case. However, the indirect object functions as a structural case, as shown by (24). Kuno provides indirect object ni marking (38a). Thus, the ni that marks the indirect object is a structural case particle in Kuno's system, which frees the system from Kuroda's limitation (iv) in relation to passivization using the indirect object.

subsection.heading: 4.4 Subjectivization
subsection.p: Sentence (18), repeated as (39), is a celebrated example of sentences with multiple nominative noun phrases given in Kuno (1973c). Multiple nominative noun phrases are restricted to sentences with stative predicates and predicates with the generic sense.

(39)
Bunmeikoku ga dansei ga heikinzyumyoo ga mizika-i.
civilized countries Nom male Nom average life span Nom short- Pres
*‘It is in civilized countries that men are such that their average life-span is short.’ 13
Kuno derives sentences like (39) by the transformational rule called Subjectivization:

(40)
Subjectivization (tentative formulation) [optional]:
Change the sentence-initial NP-no to NP-ga, and make it the new subject of the sentence.
(Kuno 1973c: 71)
Rule (40) is applied to structures like the following:

(41)
Bunmeikoku no dansei no heikinzyumyoo ga mizika-i.
Gen
Gen
Nom
By iterative application of this rule, (42) and (39) are generated step by step:

(42)
Bunmeikoku ga dansei no heikinzyumyoo ga mizika-i.
Nom
Gen
Nom
Subjectivization was extended to apply to the first noun phrase either with no or ni (locative) iteratively. (43b) is an example of Subjectivization of a locative noun phrase:

(43)
a. Sinsyuu ni taka-i yama ga takusan ar- u.
Sinsyuu Loc high mountain Nom many exist-Pres
‘In Sinsyuu there are many high mountains.’
b. Sinsyuu ga taka-i yama ga takusan ar-u.
Sinsyuu Nom Nom
Subjectivization certainly filled the gap left by Kuroda's system.
The relevant transformational rules proposed by Kuno on top of Kuroda's rules are as follows:
(44) (i) Indirect object marking, (ii) Object ga marking in a sentence with a stative predicate, (iii) ga/ni conversion, (iv) Subjectivization.

To summarize, transformational analysis of case in Japanese made various claims, which laid the foundation for later development of this area of research. Important claims are repeated in (45) given below:

(45)
a. distinction of structural cases from postpositions (unmarked vs. marked NPs in deep structure),
b. sentential complement structure for complex predicates,
c. cyclic application of case marking rules,
d. marking of the complement subject with ni,
e. linear case marking.

The following distributions of structural case particles were given special attention by those supporting transformational case marking and have continued to be targets of intensive study of case in Japanese. It is interesting to note that most of the important distributional facts about structural cases were already elucidated by the transformational study of case.

(46)
a.
ga:
i. assigned to subjects of sentences with finite predicates,
ii. assigned to objects of stative predicates,
iii. assigned to the first genitive or locative noun phrases in sentences with stative predicates (the case of multiple nominative construction).
b. o: ‘Double O Constraint.’
c.
ni:
i. assigned to subjects of certain stative predicates, those in (D), (E), and (H) in section 4.2,
ii. assigned to complement subjects of ni-causative and indirect passive,
iii. assigned to indirect objects.

The underlying principles of transformational case marking were maintained up to the end of the 1980s, with various modifications within the framework of the PPA. Among quite a number of proposals for refinements, Saito (1982), Takezawa (1987), and Kuroda (1986, 1988) will be taken up in section 5.

subsection.heading: 5 Refinements of transformational case marking under GB theory
subsection.p: Most of the works during the 1980s deal with the specifics of case marking mechanisms listed in (45). Saito (1982) makes various proposals for refinements of past works that depend upon a certain amount of specific structural devices.
Kuroda (1986) gives a detailed account of the ga marking of postpositional phrases in ‘tough sentences’ like (47):

(47)
Sensyu ni wa kono dai (kara) ga tobi- niku-i.
athlete Dat Top this springboard (from) Nom jump- hard-Pres
‘This springboard is hard for athletes to jump from.’ (Inoue 1978b: (6))

Kuroda (1986) is a detailed study of nominative case marking on the basis of the linear case marking system proposed in his work in 1978. Takezawa (1987) proposes the ‘Configurational Case-Marking’ system on the basis of GB Case theory, while Miyagawa (1989b) follows standard GB Case marking with emphasis on the distinction between arguments and adjuncts in terms of the phrase structural difference between structural case marking (Miyagawa's cliticization of case particles to the preceding NPs) and the projection of postpositions into postpositional phrases (PPs).

Kuroda (1988) makes a claim against uniform employment of agreement induced by the case checking mechanism, which was proposed in the later development of GB theory. This work of Kuroda's is a kind of bridge to the MP.

subsection.heading: 5.1 Saito (1982)
subsection.p: Saito (1982) argues against Kuno's object ga marking for sentences with stative predicates (38c) and Subjectivization (40). (Problems (46)a(ii), (iii)). He proposes to assume ga, together with ni, as a base generated inherent case marker. He starts building his theory using arguments and data from Inoue (1978b), which proposes some revision of Kuno's case marking on the basis of her analysis of ‘tough sentences’ of Japanese.
Inoue (1978b) classifies ‘tough sentences’ into the following four types:

row.entry: ‘This dictionary is easy for students to use.’ (Inoue 1978b: (1)).

subsection.p: Characteristics:

li.p: Undergoes subject ni-raising by Kuroda and object ga marking for stative sentences by Kuno, resulting in the ni-ga case alignment.
Requires that an intransitive sentence have an additional NP other than the subject.
Permits ga marking on postpositional phrases.

row.entry: ‘It has recently been hard for me to get to sleep.’ (Inoue 1978b: (10))

subsection.p: Characteristics:

li.p: Behaves like psychological predicates, expressing the subject's judgment. (See Inoue 1978b for details.)

row.entry: *‘Detergent is easy to dissolve in warm water.’ (Inoue 1978b: (25))

subsection.p: Characteristics shared by types III and IV:
The class most relevant to Saito's case system is type I, in which not only objects but also other oblique NPs originally with various postpositions are marked with ga, as shown in (48):

(48)
a. Gakusei ni wa kono zisyo ga tukai- yasu-i.
student Dat Top this dictionary Nom use- easy- Pres
‘This dictionary is easy for students to use.’ (object NP)
b. Tosiyori ni wa kono toori ga kaimono o si- niku-i.
aged people Dat Top this street Nom shopping Acc do- hard-Pres
‘This street is hard for aged people to shop around.’ (NP with de)
c. Kodomo ni wa ano isu ga suwari- niku-i.
child Dat Top that chair Nom sit- hard-Pres
‘That chair is hard for a child to sit on.’ (NP with ni)
d. Sensyu ni wa kono dai (kara) ga tobi- niku-i.
athlete Dat Top this springboard (from) Nom jump- hard-Pres
‘This springboard is hard for athletes to jump from.’ (NP with kara)
(Inoue 1978b: (1), (2), (4), (6))

What is important here is that Kuno's rules cannot account for (48b, c, d), in which postpositions are replaced by ga. (48d) even has the possibility of retaining the postposition kara. Inoue proposes to generalize the application of object ga marking to cover NPs with postpositions.

In view of these facts, Saito (1982) assumes that the nominative case particle ga is inherent in that it is base generated with an NP, whereas accusative case is assigned by the verb. First he takes up sentences with multiple subjects like (39), repeated below as (49), those with objects and oblique arguments marked with ga as in (50) and (51) respectively, and those derived by a rule called ga-no conversion, exemplified by (52b):

(49)
Bunmeikoku ga dansei ga heikinzyumyoo ga mizika-i.
*‘It is in civilized countries that men are such that their average life-span is short.’

(50)
Dare ga/ni kore ga deki- ru ka.
who Nom/Dat this Nom can-do-Pres Q
‘Who can do this?’ (Saito 1982: (3))

(51)
Sensyu ni wa kono dai (kara) ga tobi- niku-i.
athletes Dat Top this springboard from Nom jump hard-Pres
‘This springboard is hard for athletes to jump from.’ (Inoue 1978b: (6))

(52)
a. John ga hon o kai- ta.
John Nom book Acc write- past
‘John wrote a book.’
b. John ga/no kai- ta hon
Nom/Gen write- Past book
‘the book John wrote’
c. hon o/*no kai- ta John
book Acc/Gen write- Past
The sentences in (52) show that in a relative clause the nominative ga, but not the accusative o, can be converted to genitive no. 15

Saito calls the ga phrases traditionally derived by Subjectivization ‘focus with nominative case’ in order to distinguish them from the ‘subject’. He bases his assumption on distributional facts about multiple nominative phrases and semantic characteristics of sentences with them. In the first place, he argues that ga appears with a locative phrase as in (53b):

(53)
a. Los Angeles ni nihonzin ga oo- i.
Los Angeles in Japanese Nom many- Pres
‘There are many Japanese people in Los Angeles.’
b. Los Angeles ga [S nihonzin ga oo-i]
Nom
‘Los Angeles is such that many Japanese reside there.’ (Saito 1982: 7)
Next, the ungrammaticality of (54b) indicates that there should be some kind of ‘aboutness’ relation between the ga phrase and the remaining portion of the sentence:

(54)
a. [NP
ame no hi] ga tuzuite i-ru
rain Gen day Nom continuing Pres
‘It has been raining for several days.’
b. *ame ga [S hi ga tuzuite i-ru]
Nom
(Lit. ‘Rain is such that days are continuing.’) (Saito 1982: 8)

Since it is impossible to perceive an ‘aboutness’ relation between ame and the rest of the sentence, (54b) is ungrammatical. The fact that multiple nominative phrases usually appear in sentences with stative verbs and verbs with generic tense can be accounted for by this requirement of ‘aboutness’ relation, which leads to the interpretation of the rest of the sentence as a statement about a property of the subject.

The ‘focus with nominative’ phrases in (49–51) and (53) can be replaced by topic phrases. Moreover, topic phrases require the ‘aboutness’ relation as well, and might be assumed to be base generated. This gives support to the assumption of base generation of ‘focus with nominative case’. As additional support for this assumption, Saito uses the fact that ‘focus with nominative case’ behaves in the same way as topics in terms of the Double O Constraint:

row.entry: ‘This book, Mary made John read it.’ (Saito 1982: 17)

(59)

To account for all these facts Saito postulates (62), which recursively generates ‘focus with nominative case’:

(62)
S xrArr XP S, where X = [−V]
[nom.]
(Saito 1982: 16)

This rule permits free generation of “focus with nominative case,” and in order to block over-generation, exemplified by (54b), the semantic constraint in terms of ‘aboutness’ requirement is utilized.

Examples like (63) indicate that nominative case is allowed in the subject position of a nonfinite clause. It is impossible to assume that the focus phrase in the complement of (63) gets ga assigned to it by Infl of the matrix, since this implies case assignment across the sentence boundary:

(63)
[S
ame ga huri] hazime- ta
rain Nom fall start- Past
‘It started to rain.’
This is a piece of evidence in conflict with the assumption of nominative Case assignment by Infl(ection), which is one of the claims of GB Case theory.

Saito concludes, “both ‘focus’ and ‘subject’ take nominative case because nominative case marks the semantic role ‘recipient’ on the NPs that are immediately dominated by S, and their case is inherent in that it is not given by any element” (Saito 1982: 3). In this grammar, ‘focus’ and ‘subject’ are not distinct syntactic elements, but only different in the configurations in which they appear, as shown by (64):

The object and oblique phrases marked by ga, as those in (48), are also claimed to be a case of ‘focus with nominative case’. Saito's argument starts with ga marked objects in potential sentences like (34), and (28b), repeated below as (65):

(65)
a. Katoo-san ga konna muzukasi-i zi ga yom-e- ru.
Nom such difficult character Nom read-Pot- Pres
b. Katoo-san ni (wa) konna muzukasi-i zi ga yom-e-ru.
Dat Nom
‘Mr Kato can read such difficult characters.’

Compare this analysis with Kuno's. The objects are marked with ga in (65a, b) by Kuno's object ga marking for stative verbs, (38c) given above. Kuno further derives (65b) from (65a) by the ga-ni conversion rule.
Saito takes up potentials that contain oblique phrases with ga. The situation is the same as has been demonstrated with ‘tough’ sentences:

(66)
Yahari bokura ni wa [daigaku no tosyokan ga itiban otituite benkyoo deki- ru.
after all we for Top university Gen library Nom best calmly study can- Pres
‘After all, for us, the university library is the place we can study quietly.’ (Saito 1982: 64)
Using the fact that arbitrary PRO can appear only in an embedded clause as is shown by (67b), he argues for the underlying structure (67c), which he assumes for potentials like (67a):

(67)
a. Kooitta gorakueiga ga rirakkususite tanosim-e- ru.
this kind of entertainment movie Nom relaxing while enjoy-Pot- Pres
‘You can relax and enjoy this kind of entertainment movie.’ (Saito 1982: 31)
b. *PROARB kooitta gorakueiga o rirakkususite tanosim-e-ru
c. kooitta gorakueigai ga [SPROARB [ei] rirakkususite tanosim-e-ru]
A discussion in the same vein is given to type I ‘tough’ sentences, with the proposal of (68b) as the underlying structure for a type I like (68a):

(68)
a. kono hon ga (John nitotte) yomi-yasu-i (Saito 1982: 38–39)

It is concluded that the ni-phrase in potentials and the ni or nitotte phrase in ‘tough’ sentences are postpositions “that govern an argument of a verb that cannot be lexically expressed as the subject or the object” (Saito 1982: 88). Their function is that “of specifying the semantic content of the unexpressed subject” (p. 86). This generalization is claimed to account for all the functions of ni in the following constructions: (i) the subject marker in a potential sentence such as (66), (ii) the complement subject marker in ni-Causatives like (12b), (iii) the o-causative with a transitive complement sentence such as (28c), (iv) the agent marker in direct and indirect passives such as those in (14), (v) the indirect object marker in double object constructions exemplified by (13).
Thus, the case marking system is simplified tremendously in that ga and ni are treated as inherent case markers, and o is the only structural case assigned by the verb.
Finally, Saito follows Bedell's (1972) restructuring analysis of ga-no alternation in a relative clause, shown by (52), repeated below as (69):

(69)
a. John ga/no kai-ta hon.
‘The book John wrote.’
b. hon o/*no kai-ta John
The reanalysis goes as in (70):

No is assigned in the configuration (70b). Since restructuring does not leave a trace, the verb, an accusative case assigner, loses its assignee if the object NP undergoes restructuring. This is why (69b) with o-no alternation is not permitted. ga-no conversion does not cause ungrammaticality because proi remains as the case assignee in (70b).

(71) and (72) give a summary of Saito's analysis in comparison with assumptions and specific proposals made by influential transformational analyses of Japanese case, given above as (45) and (46). (The proposals explicitly or tacitly adopted by Saito are omitted.)
(45) a. the distinction of structural cases from postpositions
(71) a. The distinction is kept, but the object is the only unmarked NP, the subject being marked inherently with ga.
(45) d. marking of the complement subject with ni

(71) d. All the following functions are borne by ni as an inherent case marker: (i) the subject marker in a potential sentence such as (65b), (ii) the complement subject marker in ni-causatives like (12b), (iii) the o-causative with a transitive complement sentence such as (28c), (iv) the agent marker in direct and indirect passives such as those in (14), (v) the indirect object marker in double object constructions exemplified by (13). (Due to this analysis the structural relations among relevant sentences are left unaccounted for.)
(45) e. linear case marking
(71) e. Rejected. In accordance with GB theory, accusative case marking by the verb is assumed.
(46) a. ga: (i) assigned to subjects of sentences with finite predicates
(72) a(i) ga is an inherent case, and an NP with ga is inserted in the position dominated by S as the sister to VP (see (64b)).
(46) a. ga: (ii) assigned to objects of stative predicates
(72) a(ii) inherent case, which marks foci. It is a well-known fact that ga marked objects are not necessarily interpreted as foci. (This is one of the weaknesses of this analysis.)
(46) a. ga: (iii) assigned to the first genitive or locative noun phrases in sentences with stative predicates.
(72) a(iii) inherent case, which marks foci. (The relation between sentences with genitive such as (41) and those with nominative like (39) is lost entirely.)
(46) b. Double O Constraint
(72) b. used only as a piece of evidence for the discussion of the similarity between sentences with foci and those with topics, saying that they both obey the Double O Constraint.
(46) c. ni: (i) assigned to subjects of potential and ‘tough’ predicates, (ii) assigned to complement subjects of ni-causatives and indirect passives, (iii) assigned to indirect objects.

(72) c. ni: (i), (ii), and (iii) are treated in the same way, as postpositional phrases adjoined to S. (i) and (ii) have the ni-phrases co-indexed with PRO in the complement sentences. These postpositional phrases specify the content of the empty subject PRO. (iii) has the ni-phrase co-indexed with a lexically unexpressed object, a kind of empty category, whose content is specified by this postpositional phrase.

Even though there is not much support for Saito's claim that there is no difference between ‘focus with nominative case’ and the subject in terms of their syntactic and semantic function, this work is a step toward a unified approach to the analysis of nominatives in Japanese, which involves three distinct rules in Kuno's system, namely, subject marking, stative object ga marking, and Subjectivization. It should be noted that this work rejects structure dependent ga assignment. By positing PRO co-indexed with ‘focus with nominative case’ or the subject, both of which are dominated by S, Saito maneuvers to account for the specific syntactic and semantic role the subject plays, that is, the role as the antecedent of anaphors and as the trigger of subject-orientated honorific expressions.

subsection.heading: 5.2.1 Movement of noun phrases
subsection.p: Kuroda (1986) is an extended study of ga marking on the basis of Kuroda (1978), more specifically, Linear Case Marking (LCM), Equi and Counter Equi, and verb raising, renamed Predicate Agglutination. His careful study of type I ‘tough’ sentences has led him to contend that movement of noun phrases to subject position (A movement) is involved in the derivation of this type of construction. This analysis is extended to the analysis of multiple ga constructions.
Note first the contrast between ‘tough’ sentences and potentials as revealed by the sentences in (73) and (74):

(73)
a. Masao nitotte (wa) sono yuubinkyoku kara ga kozutumi o okuri-yasu-i.
Masao to that post office from Nom package Acc send-easy-Pres
‘It is easy for Masao to send packages from that post office.’ (‘tough’)
b. *Masao ni (wa) sono yuubinkyoku kara ga kozutumi o okur-e- ru
Acc send-Pot-Pres
‘Masao is able to send packages from that post office.’ (potential) (Kuroda 1986: (14), (15))

(74)
a. Masao nitotte (wa) sono yuubinkyoku kara kozutumi
from
ga okuri-yasu-i.
Nom (‘tough’)
b. Masao ni (wa) sono yuubinkyoku kara kozutumi
from
ga okur-e-ru.
Nom (potential)
Kuroda assumes the deep structures (75) and (76) for ‘tough’ and potential constructions respectively. [e] is in the matrix non-theta subject position.
(75) [Masao nitotte [e] [Masao sono yuubinkyoku kara kozutumi okuru] yasu-i]
(76) [Masao [Masao sono yuubinkyoku kara kozutumi okur] e-ru]
(74a) is the result of moving sono yuubinkyoku kara (‘from that post office’) to the empty subject position ([e]). To permit ga marking on this phrase, Kuroda introduces the following principle:
(77) NP movement makes an inherent case-marker (a postposition) attached to an NP invisible to LCM. (Kuroda 1986: 31)

‘Invisible’ means that LCM ignores the presence of postpositions attached to moved NPs and interprets them as unmarked NPs subject to LCM. Since no movement is involved in (74), there is only the possibility of ga marking of the object (as in (74b)), which is the first unmarked NP after Counter Equi is applied and the complement subject is marked with ni by subject ni-raising. (75) can follow the same procedure of ga marking on the object.

Thus, ga marking on postpositional phrases is permitted in ‘tough’ sentences but not in potentials. The former involves NP movement, while the latter does not. This is the cause for the difference in grammaticality.
When NP movement is applied to sono yuubinkyoku kara and object ga marking to kozutumi, the result is the multiple ga sentence (78a). A similar situation holds with potentials as revealed by (78b):

(78)
a. Masao ni totte sono yuubinkyoku kara ga kozutumi ga okuri-yasu-i.
Nom
Nom
b. Sono yuubinkyoku kara ga ookina kozutumi ga okur-e- ru.
that post office from Nom big package Nom send-Pot- Pres
‘One can send big packages from that post office.’ (Kuroda 1986: (92))

Kuroda claims that potential and ‘tough’ sentences with multiple ga phrases can be derived by Subjectivization together with those already discussed in section 4.4, namely (39), (43b), and those introduced in section 5.1 as focus phrases by Saito, namely, (53b), (56b), (57b), (58), (59), (60), and (61). Subjectivization is assumed by Kuroda as a phenomenon “which results as an effect of a rule making a constituent of a surface sentence with a stative predicate a ‘major’ subject” (Kuroda 1986: 274). “A (syntactically defined) stative predicate may be generated with a non-theta subject site Chomsky-adjoined to the main S node” (p. 274). This non-theta subject site may be filled by an argument or an adjunct moved from inside S. The deep structure of sentences of this type of subject (called ‘major’ subject) is (79a) with the surface structure (79b). (79c) is the deep structure of further multiplication of ga phrases.
Instead of nitotte, ni may appear in ‘tough’ sentences, which is the result of Counter Equi and subject ni raising in Kuroda's grammar.

subsection.heading: 5.2.2 Two types of potentials
subsection.p: As stated before, Kuroda's system does not permit postpositional phrases in potentials to get ga marked, contrary to the case of ‘tough’ sentences, since there is assumed to be no non-theta empty subject position in potentials as indicated by the deep structure (76). (80) is judged as ungrammatical by Kuroda and many other native speakers, since kono bed (‘this bed’) is originally marked with the postposition de (‘in’):

(80)
*Masao ni (wa) kono beddo ga nemur-e- ru.
Masao Dat Top this bed Nom sleep-Pot- Pres
‘Masao can sleep in this bed.’
However, there are counterexamples like (66) given by Saito (1982), repeated below as (81):

(81)
Yahari bokura ni wa [daigaku no tosyokan ga itiban otituite benkyoo deki- ru.
after all we for Top university Gen library Nom best calmly study can- Pres
‘After all, for us, the university library is the place we can study calmly.’

(82)
Kotosi wa Amerika-zin ni wa yooroppa (ni) ga yasuku ik-e- ru.
this year Top American
Top Europe
Nom cheaply go-Pot- Pres
‘Americans can go to Europe economically this year.’

Since this type of potentials typically have adverbs like itiban (‘best’) and yasuku (‘economically’), Kuroda proposes (83), similar to that of ‘tough’ sentences, for the deep structure of sentences like (81) and (82). Nitotte in (83) alternates with ni, as in the case of ‘tough’ sentences.
(83) NP1 nitotte [e] [NP1 . . . V] Adv e-ru (Kuroda 1986: (80))

subsection.heading: 5.2.3 Focus reading
subsection.p: The subject of a root (matrix) sentence with a stative predicate is interpreted as a focus, which is phrased as ‘exhaustive listing’ by Kuno. Since yasu-i (‘easy’) and niku-i (‘hard’) are adjectives and necessarily stative, the noun phrase or postpositional phrase moved to the empty subject position gets this ‘focus’ reading. Kuroda's focus is thus in sharp contrast with Saito's, which is assumed to be syntactically determined. Kuroda's focus reading is predicted by the general interpretive rule (84):
(84) The subject ga phrase of a root sentence describing a state (as opposed to a specific event, action, situation, etc.) is interpreted as ‘focused’.
The major subject is given interpretation by (84) as well.

subsection.heading: 5.2.4 Wa-ga alternation
subsection.p: The wa attachment transformation proposed in his dissertation (1965) is one of the most important theoretical contributions Kuroda made. ST assumed that transformations do not change meaning, which was called into question by this transformation because noun phrases, adverbs, verb and adjective stems assume an additional meaning ‘topic’ when they get wa attached to them. Since the time of appearance of this dissertation, topicalization has been intensively studied from the point of view of Universal Grammar. Among many questions raised in this process, the question of whether topic phrases are derived by movement transformation or are base generated is still a lively issue. Kuroda (1986) contends that all wa phrases are derived by movement.

As for the semantic distinction between wa and ga, Kuno (1973c) gives the following distinctions: wa: theme and contrast; ga: exhaustive listing, neutral description, and object marking (1973c: 38). 16 These distinctions have been accepted widely. Kuroda's focus reading, given above, corresponds to Kuno's exhaustive listing. Kuroda (1992) gives a detailed account of the judgment forms expressed by topicalized and nontopicalized sentences, more specifically the topic wa phrase as the subject in logic and the subject ga phrase as a syntactic subject. A sentence with a topic wa phrase expresses categorical judgment (subject–predicate relation in logic), while one with a subject ga phrase expresses thetic judgment, which describes perceived events.

Inoue (1982a) is a study of wa and ga as syntax and semantics interface problems. With regards to the syntactic aspect, Inoue points out that topic phrases and ga phrases with an exhaustive listing reading share the following characteristics: both must be definite or generic noun phrases, and both must permit multiple occurrences. Neither the contrastive wa nor the neutral description ga has these characteristics.

As Kuroda (1986) admits, the semantic and pragmatic functions of wa still await thorough studies before a relevant generalization emerges. Thus, an all round discussion of topic phrases will take us too much afield, so they are discussed here only with respect to wa-ga alternation.
Even though an extensive parallel distribution is observed between wa and ga, there are cases where wa phrases cannot be replaced by ga phrases as in (85c, d):

(85)
a. Masao ga eigo o hanas- u.
Masao Nom English Acc speak- Pres
‘Masao speaks English.’
b. Masao wa eigo o hanas- u.
Top English Acc speak- Pres (topicalized version)
c. Eigo wa Masao ga hanas- u.
English Top Nom speak- Pres
*‘English, Masao speaks.’
d. *Eigo ga Masao ga hanas-u
English Nom
Nom speak-Pres (subjectivized version)
(Kuroda 1986: 281)

Kuroda claims that some apparent in situ major subjects like those in (60), (61), and (66) are derived by Subjectivization, thus binding some positions in base sentences, and that subjects and major subjects can be moved to the topic position dominated by S′. In (85b) the subject Masao is topicalized, while eigo in (85d) is unable to be subjectivized due to the non-stativity of the predicate hanas (‘speak’). Even though eigo can be topicalized as in (85c), its subjectivization is impossible. In the potential sentences in (86), eigo can undergo topicalization as well as subjectivization:

(86)
a. Masao ga eigo ga hanas-e- ru.
Masao Nom English Nom speak-Pot- Pres
‘Masao can speak English.’
b. Eigo ga Masao ga hanas-e-ru. (subjectivized version)
Nom
Nom
‘It is English that Masao can speak.’
c. Eigo wa Masao ga hanas-e-ru. (topicalized version)
‘As for English, Masao can speak it.’

subsection.heading: 5.3 Takezawa (1987)
subsection.p: By ‘configurational case marking’, Takezawa means a system within GB theory which crucially uses the principle of government, 17 structurally determined on the basis of the notion of C-command. 18 Even though the works by Kuroda, Kuno, and some others use configurational structures in their grammars, their case marking systems are linear rather than configurational.

Takezawa (1987) depends fully on GB Case theory, which consists of (i) abstract Case assignment, namely Nominative is assigned by (I)nflection to the NP in the specifier position of IP, 19 while accusative is assigned by V, and (ii) Case filter (87).
(87) *NP if NP has phonetic content and has no case. (Chomsky 1981: 49)

Besides case theory Takezawa makes crucial use of Chomsky's (1981) rule R (the former affix hopping, namely, lowering tense to attach to [+V] lexical items), and S′ deletion to trigger exceptional case marking.

subsection.heading: 5.3.1 Ga marking
subsection.p: Let us start with the ga marking in Takezawa's analysis. First taken up are familiar examples (49), (50), and (51), which are representative of sentences with multiple ga phrases, the ni-ga case alignment, and postpositional phrases with ga:
(49) Bunmeikoku ga dansei ga heikinzyumyoo ga mizika-i.
‘It is in civilized countries that men are such that their average life-span is short.’
(50) Dare ga/ni kore ga deki-ru ka.
‘Who can do this?’
(51) Sensyu ni wa kono dai (kara) ga tobi-niku-i.
‘This springboard is hard for athletes to jump from.’

According to GB case theory, ga is marked by the tense dominated by Infl(ection) (Infl-tense by Takezawa). The subject of (49), heikinzyumyoo (‘average life span’) is generated in the IP Spec position, and case marked with ga by its governing head Infl-tense. The extra NPs, bunmeikoku (‘civilized countries’) and dansei (‘men’) can be similarly case marked by Infl-tense, by assuming the adjunction of these NPs to IP, generating a structure like (88):

Since in the structure (88) Infl governs all the NPs in the IP Spec position, Infl can be assumed to assign Nominative case to more than one NP, if the unique assignment of abstract case to one NP, as is assumed by GB, is discarded. Kuroda (1988) gives convincing arguments for this point. See section 5.4 for details. Ura (1996) uses the multiple nominative construction as evidence most relevant to the assumption of multiple feature checking (section 6).

Ga marking of the object of the stative predicate was first formalized by Kuno as (38c). Takezawa tries to give principled arguments, rather than a stipulative statement like (38c), to account for this phenomenon on the basis of each predicate's case assigning property. For example, wakar (‘understand’), the potential (r)are/(r)e, the passive (r)are, and the tough morpheme yasu-i/niku-i are devoid of this property. Takezawa summarizes the object ga marking mechanism in (89):

(89)
a. Stative verbs like wakar (‘understand’) do not have case assigning ability, although they have an ‘unmarked’ (i.e., non-pp) internal argument.
b. Japanese does not have a P-insertion rule analogous to English of-insertion (that inserts a dummy P to the un-case marked object position).
c. The internal argument cannot undergo movement to the subject position because the subject position is a theta position.
d. Therefore, rule R, which lowers Infl into VP, must apply to assign case to the internal argument.
e. After being moved into VP, the lowered Infl may or may not govern the subject (“optionally governs” the subject). (Takezawa 1987: 104)
The analysis of stative sentences like (50) goes as follows, using rule R:
(50) Dare ga/ni kore ga deki-ru ka?
‘Who can do this?’ (Takezawa 1987: 84)

Due to the factors listed as (89a–c), application of rule R yields the result that the internal argument kore is governed by the lowered Infl (I in (90b)) and assigned ga. Without Infl in the matrix the external argument (the subject) is no longer governed in the usual way. Here comes in the stipulation (89e). If the lowered Infl governs the subject, ga assignment to the subject takes place. Without government by Infl the subject must wait for another device to avoid the Case filter.

subsection.heading: 5.3.2 Ni marking
subsection.p: Takezawa continues his summary (89):

(89)
f. Because Japanese has a rule which inserts the dummy postposition ni after the subject when the subject is not governed by the lowered Infl, the subject of stative sentences can be marked with ni and the non-accusative case pattern is obtained (the ni-ga case array).
g. When the subject is governed, ga can be assigned to it because Infl can assign case to more than one NP in Japanese, and the double-nominative case pattern is obtained (the ga-ga case array).

Ni insertion as specified in (89f) is similar to Kuroda's subject ni-raising. However, reformulation by Takezawa makes it possible to account for case alignments in sentences with simple stative predicates, which Kuroda fails to deal with.

Ga and ni marking in stative sentences is extended to those with complex stative sentences like potentials and ‘tough’ sentences. Verb raising in the previous transformational approaches is replaced by restructuring. However, its structural effect is the same as Verb Raising, creating complex predicates in the form (91a):

In (91b) the restructured complex predicate gets the feature [−Case] percolated to the complex verb Vx from the potential morpheme (r)e, while in (91c) [+Case] of hanas (‘speak’) is percolated up to the Vx, the former deriving the ni-ga and the ga-ga potentials by means of Infl lowering and the optional government of the complement subject by the lowered Infl. [+Case] on Vx in (91c) is responsible for the ga-o potential.

For o- and ni-causative, Takezawa does not assume an extra NP for either of them. The causative formative (s)ase selects S′ as the only internal argument. The distinction between these two types of causatives is due to optional S′ deletion. The structure (92) is the deep structure of both o- and ni-causatives. Deletion of S′ makes the matrix verb (s)ase govern and assign accusative case to the complement subject in the IP Spec position, resulting in an o-causative. In case S′ deletion does not take place, S′ blocks government of the complement subject by (s)ase. Then the ungoverned subject gets ni by (89f):

subsection.heading: 5.3.3 ‘Tough’ sentences
subsection.p: Another important claim Takezawa makes is concerned with the analysis of ‘tough’ sentences. He refutes Kuroda's NP movement analysis on the basis of sentences like those in (93), in which the moved NPs, those italicized in (93a, b), are not the arguments of the verbs, which are raised and adjoined to ‘tough’ morphemes. They are in the complement sentences selected by these verbs.

(93)
a. [Kono te no zassi]j
ga (Johni nitotte) [S′ proi
maituki ej

this kind of magazine Nom John for
every month

(Lit.) ‘[This kind of magazine]j is hard (for Johni) to say to (other) people [S′ that hei takes ej regularly every month]’
b. [Zibun no otooto
kara]j
ga (Johni
nitotte) [S′ proi ej

self's brother from Nom John for
money Acc lot of borrow Pres Comp admit- hard-Pres
(Lit.) ‘[From self's brother]j is hard (for Johni) to admit [S′ that hei has borrowed a lot of money ej]’
(Takezawa 1987: 195–196)
The syntactic structure of these sentences is roughly as follows:
(94) [S NPi [AP . . . [S′ [S NP [VP . . . ei . . . V]] to] V-yasu]] (Takezawa 1987: 198)

If this is NP movement, as Kuroda claims, these traces are anaphors and must be bound in their minimal governing domain, in this case the embedded S′. Since the traces are not bound there, they violate Binding Condition A, which makes them ungrammatical, contrary to fact.

Takezawa claims that the movement, if involved in the derivation of sentences like (93a, b), must be an empty operator movement, since it seems to obey the characteristics of wh-movement: (i) it leaves a ‘gap’, (ii) where there is a bridge verb, there is an apparent violation of subjacency due to a COMP-to-COMP escape hatch; in other words, ‘long distance’ movement is possible, (iii) it observes island constraints (the Complex NP Constraint and the wh-island constraint) (Takezawa's slightly modified version of Chomsky 1977b: 86).

As a matter of fact, sentences with PP ga phrases such as (93b) show that they observe island constraints as in (95b), while those with NP ga phrases (like (93a)) are grammatical even when they violate island constraints, as shown by (95a):

(95)

this kind of magazine Nom John for every month
