o sirabe- niku- i.
this bank from Nom John for
money Acc a lot of borrow-Pres people Acc find out- hard- Pres
(Lit.) ‘From this bank is hard to find out people who borrow a lot of money.’

On the basis of this fact Takezawa concludes that ‘tough’ sentences with PP ga phrases in the subject position are derived by an empty operator movement, as shown by (96a), while those with NP ga phrases can involve either an empty operator movement or a pronominal (pro) as indicated by (96b):
(Takezawa 1987: 218)

The empty operator (0) in (96a) is co-indexed with the NP or PP, base generated in the subject position, by the predication relation. This structure is the same as that proposed by Chomsky (1977b) for English ‘tough’ sentences. Pro in (96b), on the other hand, is co-indexed with the base generated subject NP by the aboutness relation. The use of pro is proposed by Saito (1985) for topicalization of NPs and relativization, which violate the subjacency condition. Takezawa uses the fact that topicalization and relativization may involve resumptive pronouns, as was first pointed out by Perlmutter (1972). The sentences in (97) contain resumptive pronouns (cited by Saito from Kuno (1973c)):

(97)
a.[?] Sono hitoi
wa [John ga karei
no imooto o yoku sitte-i- ru rasi- i.]
that person Top John Nom him Gen sister Acc well know- Pres seem- Pres
‘Speaking of that personi, it seems that John knows hisi sister very well.’ (topicalized sentence)
b.[?] [NP [S′
watasi ga karei
no namae o wasurete-simat- ta] okyakusani]
I Nom he Gen name Acc forget- Past guest
‘the guesti who I have forgotten hisi name’ (relativized clause) (Takezawa 1987: 208–209)

Inoue (1976) shows that in Japanese resumptive pronouns appear to avoid island constraints in island contexts, and that the more complex the contexts the stronger the requirement for the use of resumptive pronouns. She also points out that the relativization of arguments generally prohibits the use of resumptive pronouns with a certain gradation among arguments and adjuncts (postpositional phrases) in their permissibility. (See Inoue 1976: 171–191 for details.)

Takezawa concludes, “Given the fact that overt resumptive pronouns and their antecedents can be related only by the ‘aboutness’ relation, phonologically null pronouns also should naturally be able to be related to their antecedents in the same way” (Takezawa 1987: 209).

Following Kuroda (1986), Takezawa admits the third possibility of ‘tough’ sentences with ga marked objects in situ. Rule R will lower Infl-tense to adjoin to the complement predicate and assign ga to the complement objects. In this case, the empty subject position remains empty, as it is claimed by Kuroda that Japanese allows the possibility of an unfilled subject position. Thus, ‘tough’ sentences with ga marked NPs have three derivations in Takezawa's grammar, namely, one involving movement of an empty operator as represented by (96a), the second with pro holding an aboutness relation with the matrix subject as in (96b), and the third with the ga marked object in situ leaving the matrix subject position unfilled.

The merit of Takezawa (1987) lies in the systematic application of GB theory to the analysis of the Japanese case system. In the framework of the PPA, this is one of the most dependable grammars. However, this structure dependent analysis of case along the PPA is replaced by agreement based case theory of the MP due to the elimination of theoretical artifacts like ‘government’ from the MP.

subsection.heading: 5.4 Kuroda (1988)
subsection.p: Kuroda (1988) is an attempt to solve problems involving the Japanese case system in the framework of the PPA. More specifically, he casts doubt on the Case theory of the PPA, which has Case checking by means of Agreement as its core. His conclusion is, “languages are parameterized as to whether Agreement is forced or not,” and that Japanese is a language with non-forced Agreement.

Languages with forced agreement are subject to the principle of the uniqueness of agreement: An agreement inducing base category agrees with at most one Max (X) (maximal projection of X). This principle accounts for the fact that English, as a language with forced agreement, permits only one subject and one object per sentence. As a corollary from this principle it follows that languages with non-forced agreement are free from the uniqueness constraint. A clear cut support for this principle comes from the existence of multiple subjects in Japanese, exemplified by (39) and (43b) in section 4.4.

How about objects in Japanese? We have already mentioned a well-known constraint, the Double O Constraint (DOC), which is counter to Kuroda's claim. However, Kuroda goes on to deny the DOC itself, using the fact that unacceptability is ameliorated by clefting, which places adjacent o phrases apart from each other, as is shown by (98):

(98)
a. *Masao ga ano uma o
ano mon o
toosita.
Masao the horse the gate pass through
‘Masao passed the horse through the gate.’
(Kuroda 1988: (28))
b. Masao ga ano uma o toosita no wa ano mon o da.
‘It was that gate that Masao passed the horse through.’
(Kuroda 1988: (29))
c. Masao ga ano mon o toosita no wa ano uma o da.
‘It was that horse that Masao passed through that gate.’
(Kuroda 1988: (30))

Kuroda renames his linear case marking (used in 1978) as lower-case case marking and assumes that this case marking applies in deep structure. He admits the case marking (abstract case marking) by the PPA into his system as the case assignment to bare object noun phrases like those in (99) (a bare noun phrase = a noun phrase without a case particle):

(99)
a. Masao wa dono uma o dono mon toosita no?
‘Which gate did Masao let which horse go through?’
b. Masao wa dono mon o dono uma toosita no?

Dono mon (which gate) in (99a) is a bare noun phrase, whereas in (99b) dono uma is a bare noun phrase. The bare NPs in (99) are case checked by the head verb. Those with o are the result of the lower-case case marking.

Thus, Kuroda concludes, “a verb in Japanese may subcategorize for more than one object,” and “the verb agrees with (assigns case to) only one of them; the other is licensed by lower-case case” (1988: 337).

However, ‘case-drop’ as in (99) is observed only in colloquial Japanese, whereas it is nonexistent in the formal standard Japanese, where all argument noun phrases are case marked. This means that all arguments are licensed by lower-case case marking.

It is significant that Kuroda dropped his former claim that the o phrases like mon o in (98), with the theta-role path, are adverbial, and that the particle o here is a postposition, not a case particle. Now he says, “I take the term object broadly and mean by it any complement of a verb that potentially receives case from it, that is, in other words, a complement of a verb which is not inherently case marked” (p. 337).
There are two other constructions Kuroda assumes to contain two objects, as in (100) and (101) given below:

(100)
a. Masao ga Hanako no hoho o butta.
Masao Hanako cheek hit
‘Masao hit Hanako's cheek.’
b. *Masao ga Hanako o hoho o butta.
c. Masao ga Hanako o butta no wa hoho (o) da.
d. Masao ga hoho o butta no wa Hanako (?o) da. (Kuroda 1988: (35))

(101)
a. Masao ga kono sakazuki ni ano sake o mitasita.
this sake-cup that sake fill
‘Masao filled that sake in this cup.’
b. Masao ga ano sake de kono sakazuko o mitasita.
‘Masao filled this cup with that sake.’
c. *Masao ga kono sakazuki o ano sake o mitasu.
d. ?Masao ga kono sakazuki o mitasita no wa ano sake o da.
e. ?Masao ga ano sake o mitasita no wa kono sakazuki o da.
(Kuroda 1988: (44a–e))

On the basis of (100c, d) and (101d, e), in which the DOC is ameliorated by clefting, Kuroda assumes both (100a) and (101a) have double o constructions at some stages of the derivation. The particle o is distributed from the head hoho (‘cheek’) to Hanako, which is adjoined to it in the NP Hanako no hoho (‘Hanako's cheek’). The predicate mitasu (‘fill’) in (101), on the other hand, is assumed to subcategorize for two objects. Thus, there are three double o constructions, the first, the second, and the third exemplified by (98), (100), and (101) respectively.

Kuroda's admission of double o constructions reveals the difficulty of setting a fast dividing line between structural and inherent cases. This fact is further elaborated in Inoue (1997a) motivating her claim that some inherent cases should not be excluded from syntactic accounts of case in Japanese.

In this grammar of Kuroda's, a subject is generated as Ext(V), the external argument of V, with the possibility of another subject and possibly still another adjoined to the same Max(V). These subject positions are not the case position, but the ga assigned by the lower-case case marking in deep structure licenses subject NPs. Ext(I) is not a case position, either, but the landing site for scrambled elements. Subjects thus generated in Ext(V) do not have to move to Ext(I) unless it is scrambled.
There are three multiple subject constructions, as exemplified by the sentences in (102–104).

(102)
a. Zoo ga hana ga nagai.
elephant
trunk
long
‘Elephants have long trunks.’ (derived by Subjectivization of (102b) (Kuroda 1988: (45))
b. Zoo no hana ga nagai.
‘Elephants’ trunks are long.’

(103)
a. Kono koma ga iro ga kirei da. (Kuroda 1988: (48))
this top
color
beautiful
‘This top is a pretty color.’
b. #Kono koma no iro ga kirei da. 20
(Kuroda 1988: (49))

(104)
a. Watasi ga mizu ga hosii.
I water
want
‘I want water.’ (Kuroda 1988: (56))
b. *Watasi no mizu ga hosii. (Kuroda 1988: (57))

While (102a) is the result of subjectivization, discussed in section 4.4, the (a) sentences of (103) and (104) are assumed to have different derivational processes. The double subjects in (103) are the result of distributed ga assignment to the underlying structure (103b) just in the way o phrases are distributed in (100). The ga marked object in (104a) is claimed to be a subject on some semantic grounds, with the predicate hosi-i, -ta-i, and the like subcategorizing for two subjects. Both these subjects are generated as Ext(V), one of which is adjoined to Max(V). All the multiple ga phrases in these three constructions may stay in the Ext(V) position unless scrambled out to the Ext(I) position.
These facts about o and ga phrases naturally follow from Kuroda's assumption that languages with nonforced Agreement do not obey the uniqueness condition.

In restrospect, the transformational approach to the study of case in Japanese pointed out most issues relevant to this area of research through careful study of crucial data, which have been repeatedly used in attempts to build up theories of explanatory adequacy.

subsection.heading: 6 Studies of case in Japanese on the basis of the Minimalist Program
subsection.p: This section picks up only a few of the works relevant to the future development of this research area since it is impossible to make a general survey of the present state of research development in the fast changing theoretical framework.

Marantz (1992) is discussed because this work indicates a break from the syntactic analysis of case, establishing morphological structure (MS) as a representation between surface structure (SS) and phonological form (PF), as shown by (105). This approach is elaborated in Halle and Marantz (1993). Let us call this approach ‘morphological case theory’, following Aoyagi (1998).

This claim reflects one of the factors deciding a new direction of research in the MP since the MP reduces the functions of syntax to the minimum. Marantz (1995a) describes the MP as a computational system, a simple system of compositions, “constrained by a small set of economy principles, which Chomsky claims enforce the general requirement, ‘do the most economical things to create structures that pass the interface conditions’.” He continues, “Chomsky's vision of the end of syntax should have the positive consequence of forcing syntacticians to renew their interface credentials by paying serious attention to the relevant work in phonology and semantics.” The addition of MS on the PF branch is certainly a necessary step for the development of a theory.

Aoyagi (1998) presents the Japanese case system based on Marantz's morphological case theory. This is an extensive study of the distribution of case particles in relation to the relational particles wa (topic marker) and mo (‘also’) and adverbial particles such as dake (‘only’) and sae (‘even’). Since a review of the whole work would take up too much space, only Aoyagi's case particle assignments, which are in fact a morphological spell-out of case features, will be reviewed.

Next, we take up Watanabe (1996), a revised version of his dissertation (1993a), which adopts agr(eement) based syntactic case checking for licensing argument NPs, a standard practice at that time. Koizumi (1995, 1998) follow this work. Ura (1996, 1999, 2000, 2001) are reviewed to the extent that they contain discussions relevant to the comparison with Watanabe's proposal for a system using a case checking mechanism without AgrP.
Finally, we review Fukui and Takano (1998), which discards the Case checking mechanism altogether, employing the function of case particles as licensers of NPs (or DPs).
All the reviews may be unduly brief, but this is inevitable due to the nature of these works reflecting the instability of the rapidly evolving theoretical models.

subsection.heading: 6.1.1 Marantz (1992)
subsection.p: Marantz (1992) claims that the “mapping between semantic roles and argument positions, augmented by the subject requirement of the Extended Projection Principle (EPP), is suficient to license NPs in argument positions” (p. 234). This means that if abstract case theory functions only in licensing NPs, not in deciding actual case realization, it is eliminable from syntax. He shows that this is in fact true, using facts about Georgian with its split ergative system, Icelandic with its quirky case, and some other languages with rich morphological case and agreement.

It is well known that theta positions, positions assigned theta-roles by predicates, are relevant to abstract case assignment. This situation is depicted by Burzio's generalization, given below as (106).
(106) Burzio's generalization: A verb (with an object) case-marks its object if and only if it theta-marks its subject. (Chomsky 1986b: 139)

Marantz discusses the case of Georgian, in which nominative case on the subject and dative case (dative = accusative) on the object appear in present, future, and other ‘series I’ tenses, while in the aorist or simple past (‘series II’) ergative case and nominative case are found on the subject and the object respectively. Furthermore, ergative case is restricted to subjects of transitive and unergative sentences, excluding derived subjects of unaccusatives. This means that ergative case does not appear when the predicate requires a non-thematic subject. This fact is stated as the ‘ergative case generalization’, given below as (107):
(107) Ergative case generalization: Even when ergative case may go on the subject of an intransitive clause, ergative case will not appear on a derived subject. (Marantz 1992: (6))
Such distribution of ergative case cannot be accounted for by abstract case theory.

Moreover, Georgian agreement is always based on the Nom-Dat pattern even when morphological case alignment follows the Erg-Nom pattern in the aorist. This means that the subject position is licensed by tense/aspect inflection. The Ergative case generalization is thus about the morphological realization of case on subjects, not about NP licensing, while Burzio's generalization is meant to be about NP licensing.
However, Marantz argues that there are cases in English where predicates, requiring a non-thematic subject position, still assign accusative case, as in (108).

(108)
a. It struck me that I should have used ‘Elmer’ in the sentence.
b. There struck me as being too many examples in his paper.
c. Elmeri struck her as [ti being too stubborn for the job].
(Marantz 1992: (13))
As is shown by the sentences in (108), strike requires a non-thematic subject position, but it assigns case to the objects, me and her in (108).

Marantz further argues that the typical examples supporting abstract case theory, those in (109), can be accounted for by the EPP and an assumption that “movement comes for free while insertion of a dummy subject in environments (deep structures like (109e, f)) is a last resort option for satisfying the Extended Projection Principle (EPP)” (Marantz 1992: 240).

(109)
a. The man arrived. b. The porcupine was sold.
c. *It arrived the man. d. *It was sold the porcupine.
e. e arrived the man. f. e was sold the porcupine.
These facts make Marantz conclude that abstract case theory is eliminable from the theory of syntax.

Noting the similarity between the two generalizations, Burzio's and ergative, namely, that they both depend upon the presence of the thematic subject position, Marantz introduces the idea of ‘dependent’ case in his case realization disjunctive hierarchy, shown in (110):
(110) Case realization disjunctive hierarchy:
a. lexically governed case (so called inherent case),
b. ‘dependent’ case (accusative and ergative),
c. unmarked case (environment-sensitive),
d. default case. (Marantz 1992: (29))

(a) = takes precedence over everything else, for example, the Icelandic quirky case (lexically governed) is preserved when an NP moves from its original position, where it is marked by the quirky case, to a position of nominative or an ECM accusative case position. (b) = Acc and Erg are assigned by V+I to one argument position in opposition to another argument position (dependent case):
(111) Dependent case is assigned by V+I to a position governed by V+I when a distinct position governed by V+I is:
a. not ‘marked’ (not part of a chain governed by a lexical case determiner),
b. distinct from the chain being assigned dependent case.
(c) for example, genitive may be the unmarked case inside NPs (or DPs) while nominative may be the unmarked case inside IP's. (d) appears when no other case realization principle is available.

subsection.heading: 6.1.2 Aoyagi (1998)
subsection.p: Marantz assumes V-to-I movement, which makes him set the condition of dependent case realization as in (111b). Aoyagi rephrases it without using V+I:
(112) A dependent case is assigned to a thematic position in a given domain (e.g., a finite tense) when there is a distinct unmarked thematic position in the same domain.
Aoyagi schematizes dependent case assignments as follows:

(113)
a. Ergative languages Transitives (unergatives) b. Unaccusatives/passives
c. Accusative languages Transitives d. Unaccusatives/passives
(Aoyagi 1998: 91–92)

In (113a) DP2 can refer to DP3, a distinct unmarked thematic position, so it has ERG assigned to it, while in (113b) t2 is not a distinct unmarked position because it forms a chain with DP2. This accounts for the fact that ERG cannot be assigned to a derived subject. In (113c) DP3 can refer to DP2, the thematic subject position for DP3 to refer to, while in (113d) the subject position is non-thematic, and may be filled by an expletive, so Acc cannot be assigned to DP2, which ends up with the default case particle ga.

Now let us follow Aoyagi's application of this idea to the analysis of the Japanese case system. First, Kuroda's canonical sentence patterns are slightly modified with the addition of the inherent case ni in the transitive case alignment.

(114)
a. (Di)transitive: NOM-(DAT)-ACC
b. Ergative: DAT-NOM
Intransitive: NOM
In Marantz's case realization hierarchy, DAT (ni) is lexically governed, ACC (o) is dependent, and NOM (ga) is unmarked or default in Japanese.

(115)
a. (Di)transitive Pattern (John ga Mary ni hon o age-ta.) (‘John gave Mary a book.’) b. ‘Ergative’ Pattern (John ni tetugaku ga wakar-u.) (‘John understands philosophy.’)
c. Intransitive pattern (Mary ga hasit-ta.) (‘Mary ran.’)

In (115a) DP4 (hon) can refer to DP2 in the unmarked distinct theta position, but not to DP3 (Mary-ni) in the inherently marked position. Since DP2 meets the condition of dependent case assignment, DP4 is assigned ACC. In (115b) DP3 (tetugaku) cannot refer to any unmarked distinct theta position; thus it is unable to get ACC assigned to it. Instead, it gets the default ga. The same situation holds in (115c).

The merit of dependent case theory is its capacity of giving a principled basis for Burzio's generalization together with the ergative principle within the framework of the morphological case system. Dependent case theory succeeds in specifying interrelationships of structural case particles. Aoyagi's work supports this hypothesis with data from Japanese. Unfortunately, the main theme of this work, the study of relative distributional facts among case particles, relational and adverbial particles, cannot be taken up in this review.

subsection.heading: 6.2 Watanabe (1996)
subsection.p: As a modification of the Agr-based case theory of Chomsky (1991, 1993), Watanabe proposes the Three-Layered Case Checking Hypothesis, which does not make use of the notion of government but employs an X-bar theoretical scheme with a crucial notion of the Spec–head and head–complement relations. Chomsky's Agr-based case theory adopts the split INFL Hypothesis by Pollock (1989), which is extended by Watanabe in (116) as the basis of the full clause structure:

subsection.heading: 6.2.1 Nominative and accusative case checking
subsection.p: According to Agr-based case theory, the configuration necessary for both nominative and accusative case checking is (117), where X stands for case-bearing heads, the finite Tns for Nominative, a verb for Accusative, the infinitival Tns for null case borne by PRO:
The DPs with nominative and accusative Case feature are moved to the Agr-Spec positions after the case-bearing heads are adjoined to Agr, as shown by (118a, b):

(118)
a. Movement of a DP with the case feature accusative
(Watanabe 1996: (1.12) slightly modified)
b. Movement of a DP with the case feature nominative

In (118a) the movement of the object DP is legitimate due to the minimal domain created by the adjunction of the case-bearing head V to Agr. In other words, the Spec of Agr-oP and the Spec of VP are equidistant from the object DP. 22 The nominative case feature is checked after the VP internal subject DP is moved to the Spec of Agr-sP as in (118b). For Watanabe, case checking is the transference of the case feature of the DP in the Spec of AgrP to Agr. Thus case checking is carried out between the DPs and the case-bearing heads standing in the Spec–head relation.

subsection.heading: 6.2.2 Follow-up case checking
subsection.p: On top of this basic assumption of the mechanism of Agr-based case checking, Watanabe makes precise the notion of case absorption crucially used to account for universal syntactic phenomena like passivization. His original contribution is his assumption of follow-up checking. In (118b) the DP, the VP internal subject, moves to the Agr-Spec position carrying the case feature [Nom], which is checked and transferred to Agr-s. The feature [Nom] copied onto Agr will become invisible in LF together with Agr itself. However, the feature [Nom] borne by Tns remains, waiting for elimination by the end of LF. Using he as an example of the subject DP, Watanabe gives (119a) as the syntactic representation after [Agr Tns Agr] is adjoined to C:
The feature [Nom] transferred onto Agr will become invisible in LF together with Agr itself.
Now the [Nom] of Tns is checked by the follow-up checker C0 that, as in (119b):

Similarly V0 with [Acc] is first adjoined to Agr and checks the [Acc] carried by the object DP, transferring its case feature to Agr. Then [Agr V0 Agr] is adjoined to Tns, which checks the [Acc] carried by V0. Thus, the follow-up checker for [Acc] borne by V0 is Tns.
The follow-up case checking hypothesis accounts for the legitimate and illegitimate appearances of PRO as embedded subjects, whose structures are assumed to be (120a) and (120b) respectively.

(120)
a. John tried [CP e [Agr-sP PRO to win the race]] (control construction)
b. *John believed [Agr-sP PRO to have won the race] (ECM construction)
(Watanabe 1996: (2.13))

The null Case feature borne by PRO is checked off by the same case feature of the infinitival Tns. This much is the same in both (120a and b). However, the follow-up case checking is possible only in (120a) thanks to the presence of empty C0 (e in (120a)), the head of CP, while (120b), which lacks CP, is not allowed this possibility. Thus, this hypothesis accounts for this distributional fact without using the PRO theorem based on the notion of government. 23

subsection.heading: 6.2.3 Case absorption
subsection.p: In case there is no follow-up checker in the appropriate position, as in the case of (120b), case absorption rather than case checking takes place, putting the case feature of the head onto Agr leaving the case feature of a DP unchecked. Now the DP must move to a position where its case feature can be checked. In the ECM construction, whose embedded clause is IP, rather than CP with the follow-up checker C0, the embedded subject DP must move to Agr-o-Spec to get its [Acc] checked by V0 adjoined to Agr-o. The follow-up checking of [Acc] on V0 is carried out by Tns.
In the case of a Participial Passive such as (121a), the structure (121b) is assumed, omitting the ‘by phrase’ and including only relevant positions:

(121)
a. He was scolded by Mary. (Watanabe (3.2b))
b.
(Watanabe 1996: (3.4))

Since the verb be cannot check off [Acc], case absorption takes place transferring the [Acc] of the participle scolded to Agr. Agr can take only one case feature, so the object DP has to move to the Agr-sP-Spec position in order to get its remaining case feature checked off.
Parallel to the participial passive, the Japanese direct passive like (122a) is assumed to have (122b) as its underlying structure:

(122)
a. John ga Mary ni sikar-are-ta
b.
(structurally the same as Watanabe 1996: (3.86))

The passive morpheme (r)are, which corresponds to be in (121b), does not project an external argument, nor does it carry the accusative case feature. In contrast, the indirect passive morpheme (r)are projects an experiencer external argument and has the accusative case feature. The indirect passive like (123a) is assumed to have (123b) as its underlying structure:

(123)
a. John-ga Mary-ni kodomo-o sikar-are-ta
b.
(structurally the same as Watanabe 1996: (3.87))

Since there is no follow-up checker beyond Agr in (122b), Agr absorbs the feature [Acc] borne by V0 sikar leaving the DP John-ga with [Acc]. Thus, John-ga must move through the Spec of the embedded AgrP to the matrix Spec of Agr-sP to get its nominative case feature checked off, which results in the case switch from accusative to nominative.

As for the indirect passive, the object DP gets its case feature [Acc] checked in the matrix Agr-oP by (r)are with the same feature. The DP in the lower VP-Spec position in the indirect passive is assumed to stay there as an argument of V0, to account for the fact that it binds an anaphor in the embedded clause. 24 The embedded subject DP in the direct passive is adjoined to the VP, since it is devoid of this capacity. Observe the following contrast:

(124)
a. *John ga Maryi
niyotte zibuni
no heya ni tozikome- rare- ta.
John Nom Mary by self Gen room in lock up- Pass- Past
‘John was locked up in her room by Mary.’ (direct passive)
b. Tom ga Maryi
ni John o zibuni
no heya ni tozikome- rare- ta.
Tom Nom Mary Dat John Acc self Gen room in lock up- Pass- Past
‘Tom was adversely affected by Mary's locking up John in her room.’ (indirect passive)
(Watanabe 1996: (3.116a, b))
Schematically the direct and indirect passive have (125a, b) respectively as underlying structures:

(125)
a. [VP BE [AgrP Agr VP]
b. [VP Experiencer V [AgrP Agr VP] (Watanabe 1996: (3.136))

subsection.heading: 6.2.4 Causatives
subsection.p: There is a type of causative, called the reduced causative, which shares a similar structure and syntactic behavior with the indirect passive, as shown by (126). It is to be noted that the reduced causative embeds a simple AgrP, which allows the embedded object o to get to the matrix Agr-oP moving through its Spec.
(126) [VP Agent V Caus [AgrP Agr VP]]

In this type of causative, the embedded object becomes the subject of the direct passive. The Japanese o-causative like (28c), with an embedded transitive sentence, does not permit this possibility, as is indicated by (127b), while the passivization with the embedded subject is legitimate, as in (127c):

(127)
a. Katoo-san ga kodomo ni nimotu o hakob- ase- ta. (= (28c))
Katoo Nom child Dat baggage Acc carry- Caus- Past
‘Mr Kato made the child carry the baggage.’
b. *Nimotu ga Katoo-san niyotte kodomo ni hakob-ase-rare-ta.
c. Kodomo ga Katoo-san ni(yotte) nimotu o hakob-ase-rare-ta.

In the reduced causative with an embedded transitive sentence case absorption takes place as in the case of the direct passive, that is, the Agr in the embedded clause takes in the accusative case feature of the embedded verb, so that the DP with [Acc] must move to the Spec of the matrix Agr-oP to get its Case feature checked off. With an intransitive embedded sentence, the complement subject DP simply moves to the matrix Agr-sP for feature checking, since there is no case feature borne by the verb.
Japanese causatives are not of this type as is clear from the contrast in (127). Watanabe assumes the underlying structure (128) for causative sentences like (127a):
(128) [VP Agent VCaus [AgrP Agr-s [TP T [AgrP Agr-o VP]]]]

The subject DP must stay in its original position, Spec of the embedded VP, in overt syntax to achieve its function of binding an anaphor. It is not possible for this DP to move to the matrix Spec of Agr-oP in LF because the Agr-o chain created by adjunction of its head onto Tns is not available at LF due to deletion of Agr there. Oblique marking of the embedded subject (in Japanese by ni) saves this situation, that is, there is no need for movement of the subject DP. The object DP under the embedded VP gets its case feature checked in Agr-oP followed by follow-up checking by Tns in LF.
Causative passives such as (127c) are assumed to have something like (129) as their underlying structure:

In this case the subject DP is assumed to move to the Spec of the matrix Agr-sP in overt syntax before the object DP is moved to the embedded Spec of Agr-oP in LF. Thus, there is nothing blocking the movement of the subject. The embedded object has to be raised to the Agr-oP-Spec to get its case checked in LF. Thus, there is no hope of the embedded object turning to the passive subject, a result consonant with the fact revealed in (127). The causer argument gets an oblique marking.

So far we have seen the mechanism of the Three-Layered Case Checking System 25 as a representative of the refinement of Agr-based case theory. This theory clearly laid an important step toward a refinement of the new theory, discarding the government based case theory of the PPA.

As Watanabe admits, the main concern of this work is the licensing of argument DPs, rather than case realization. As far as the issues taken up in this work and the solutions given to them are concerned, it does not seem to have added very much to the empirical study of case in Japanese. However, its value lies in the fact that within the framework of the MP this theory gives an account of a variety of linguistic facts revealed by past works on quite a number of languages. In this respect the analysis of the Japanese case system in this framework has played an important role in leading the theory toward establishing a better universal grammar. As stated before, this work is not aimed at dealing with a wide range of facts about case realizations. Take for example the Japanese nominative ga, which appears not only with the subject of a finite clause or multiple subjects but also with the object of a stative predicate. Possible case alignments in major sentence structures such as potential and ‘tough’ sentences are actually out of consideration of this work. Therefore, from the point of view of case realization, it is doubtful whether or not efforts to deal with all these facts on the basis of this theory will prove to be revealing.

subsection.heading: 6.3 Koizumi (1998)
subsection.p: Koizumi (1998) is taken up in this review, as it offers an alternative mechanism supporting Watanabe's Three-Layered Case hypothesis originally proposed in Watanabe (1993a). Koizumi bases his argument on this version rather than the revised one (1996) reviewed in the preceding section. However, the gist of Koizumi's claim is not affected by Watanabe's new case checking mechanism, namely the follow-up case checking described in section 6.2. Koizumi claims that Japanese, lacking overt morphological agreement, has an invisible AgrP, which motivates object raising. He uses as evidence the scope interaction between the delimiter dake (‘only’) and three types of Japanese complex predicates, namely, raising, control, 26 and stative predicates exemplified by the sentences in (130):

(130)
a. John wa niku dake o tabe-sugi- ta.
John Top meat only Acc eat- overdo-Past (raising predicate)
‘John overdid eating only meat.’
i. only > overdo
(‘Among many things John ate, it is only meat that he overate.’)
ii. overdo > only
(For too long time, John ate nothing but meat.)
(Koizumi 1998: (9))
b. John wa ringo dake o tabe-wasure-ta.
Top apple only Acc eat- forget- Past (control predicate)
‘John forgot to eat only apples.’
i. only > forget
(‘Among many things John was supposed to eat, it is only apples that he forgot to eat.’)
ii. *forget > only (It is eat only apples that John forgot to do.)
(Koizumi 1998: (11))
c. John ga migime dake o tumur-e-ru.
Nom right eye only Acc close Pot-Pres (potential with Acc)
‘John can close only his right eye.’
i. can > only (‘John can wink his right eye.’)
ii. ?*only > can (It is only his right eye that he can close.)
(Koizumi 1998: (25a))
d. John ga migime dake ga tumur-e- ru.
Nom right eye only Nom close-Pot-Pres (potential with Nom)
‘John can close only right eye.’
i. *can > only
ii. only > can (Koizumi 1998: (25b))

In (130a) with a raising predicate sugi- (‘over-’), the object in the complement sentence can take both narrow (embedded) and wide (matrix) scopes, which causes the ambiguity shown in the interpretations (i) and (ii), while in (130b) with a control predicate the narrow scope reading of the complement object is disallowed as indicated by the reading (ii) with a star. As for potentials, it was already stated in section 4 ((31) in particular) that the potentials (r)are, (r)e require matrix and complement subjects in deep structure. In terms of GB theory, potentials theta-mark their external arguments resulting in the requirement of the PRO complement subject. In other words, they are control predicates. (130c) does not conform to the descriptive generalization given above, revealing a scope phenomenon (narrow scope) different from (130b) with a control predicate. However, (130d) with the complement object marked with the nominative ga shows that only the wide scope reading is permitted as is the case with control predicates.

The relevant question to ask about the facts given above is: How can we account for (i) the fact that the raising predicate permits narrow and wide scope interpretations for the complement object, (ii) the fact that the control predicate permits only wide scope interpretation, and (iii) the fact that the potential with the o-marked complement object does not permit wide scope reading, while the ga-marked complement object permits only wide scope reading?

Koizumi (1998) and Watanabe (1996) share the basic mechanism of Case checking, namely, raising both Case bearing heads (V with [Acc] and T with [Nom]) and the case checked DPs to the same checking domains. V and the object DP are raised to the checking domain of Agr-o, whereas T and the Subject DP go to that of Agr-s. The resulting structures are the same as (118a and b) in Watanabe's system. In Watanabe, case checking is transference of the case feature of DP to Agr, while in Koizumi case checking is carried out by copying the case features of DP and V or T to Agr. If the two copied features are of the same type, case checking is successful. Thus, Koizumi's case checking is carried out by case matching. Watanabe motivates follow-up case checking by the obligatory elimination of case features left with the case bearing heads, since case features are uninterpretable. Koizumi motivates the same three-step process by the invisibility of Agr with copied features at the LF interface, where the success of the case matching is checked. Thus, the feature copied on Agr must be copied onto the lexical elements T or C, which have semantic contents and are visible in LF. This corresponds to Watanabe's follow-up checking. The structures for the three-step case checking are the same as Watanabe's structures (119a and b) for follow-up case checking.
On top of this basic mechanism, Koizumi provides the following condition on feature copying:
(131) Features may be copied to an item with an original case feature, but they may not be recopied from that item.

In the partial structure (132), the case features previously copied to AgrO from the object and the verb can be copied to T with the original case feature [NOM], but not to C due to the intervening T with the original case feature.

Now let us see how the three questions raised in connection with the data given in (130) are answered. The raising verb, V2 in (133) given below, is without the case feature [ACC]. When AgrO1 receives [ACC] from V1 (the embedded verb) and its object, these features can be copied onto T since V2 is without a case feature. This means that feature copying within the domain of AgrO1 licenses the object, so it takes the narrow scope, i.e., the embedded scope. When V1 is raised to V2 without its case feature copied to AgrO1, the case feature [ACC] is transferred to V2. Now the object of V1 cannot be licensed within the domain of AgrO1. Thus, it has to move to the Spec of AgrO2, where it is licensed and yields the wide scope reading. The raising of an embedded verb to the matrix verb, specified as Restructuring, is optional in the case of raising predicates, which is the source of ambiguity between wide and narrow scope readings.

(133) V2 = Raising
(Koizumi 1998: (33))

In the case of control verbs, both V1 and V2 have [ACC], so that [ACC] copied onto AgrO1 cannot be recopied to T due to the presence of V2 with the original case feature [ACC] (Condition (131)). Since the third step, copying the case feature carried by AgrO1 onto T, is imposssible, the complement object must move to the Spec of AgrO2 to get licensed. This is why control predicates permit only the wide scope reading. (134) is the intermediate structure of the control predicates relevant to the feature copying mechanism:

(134) V2 = Control
(Koizumi 1998: (34))

The potentials are control predicates, but without [ACC], so AgrO1 with the Case features copied onto it from V1 and its object can be recopied to T without being blocked by V2. This is the reason for the narrow scope reading. When V1 is raised to V2, its Case feature is tranferred to V2 as in the case of raising predicates. The object with [NOM] must be adjoined to TP to get its case feature checked in the domain of AgrS. The two case features carried by T are recopied onto C. This is the cause of the wide scope reading for the nominative object in (130d).

Koizumi claims that Japanese, without overt morphological agreement, has AgrP, using the scope interactions observed in sentences with complex predicates exemplified by those in (130). To be more specific, unless object movement to AgrP-Spec is assumed, the scope interactions cannot be accounted for, since the differences of interpretations are dependent on the positions of the specifiers of AgrP, either in the embedded or the matrix clause, that moved complement objects occupy.
Koizumi's work is supported by the fact of Scandinavian languages, which are reported to have overt object raising. Thus, this work is interesting in terms of UG.

Now that Agr as a functional head has been discarded, how to account for these facts in the framework of the MP is the problem for all those who have worked on Agr-based case theory. In the appendix to his chapter 1, Watanabe (1996) casts his case checking system in the new framework without Agr, which is given in section 6.4.1.

subsection.heading: 6.4.1 From Agr-based case checking to Agr-less
subsection.p: Ura (1996) gives a solution to the problem as to how to switch from Agr-based case checking to Agr-less case checking. To avoid involvement in too much theory internal discussion, this section concentrates on Ura's proposal relevant to Watanabe's case checking.

In order to capture the essence of his Layered Case Checking hypothesis without the use of Agr, Watanabe gives basic ideas for the modifications of his theory given in section 6.2. First he proposes that nominative and null case checking are carried out in TP, as in (135):

For accusative case checking, Watanabe makes crucial use of the multiple Specifier construction proposed in Chomsky (1995c) and followed by Ura, the gist of which is given below after presenting Watanabe's idea.

Vb in (136a, b) is v in Ura, which stands for a light verb representing a transitive verb. As is shown by (136a) the Subj is in Vb-Spec as in the standard case, while the moved Obj occupies another Vb-Spec position. This means, according to Ura, that Vb allows multiple spec positions due to its parametric positive value of ‘violability of procrastinate’. Procrastinate is an economy condition that forces the choice of movement in LF (covert movement) over that in syntax (overt movement). There is assumed a parametric variation of verbs between those permitting violation of this condition and those disallowing it. Since the violability is optional, i.e., not forced on all the verbs but tolerated by some verbs, it is called by Ura ‘an unforced violation of procrastinate’. When the head verb has this property, it projects multiple specifier positions as landing sites of moved elements. Thus, (136b) is a legitimate structure.

subsection.heading: 6.4.2 Mutiple feature checking
subsection.p: Ura (1996) is concerned with the explication under the MP of the widely observed facts that grammatical relations (GR), subject, object, and so on, do not always show one-to-one correspondences to grammatical functions (GF) such as playing the role of the antecedent of a reflexive form, the controller of the PRO subject of an adjunct clause, 27 or the trigger of the so-called subject triggered honorification in Japanese. Ura calls the discrepancy between GR and GF Grammatical Function Splitting (GFS). Typical examples of GFS can be drawn from facts about various types of ergative languages (Ura 1996, 2000). GFSs are observed in syntactic, morphological, and mixed ergativity. Take for example the case system of Georgian, which Marantz (1992) describes. In Georgian morphological ergativity is observed in sentences with simple past tense while accusativity shows up in sentences with the other tense forms. Furthermore, the agreement is dependent on the accusative case system. Now we can see that case analysis cannot be determined solely in terms of structural configurations. Due to space limitation, it is impossible to summarize Ura's arguments for the necessity of multiple feature checking to deal with such problems. The gist of the multiple feature checking Ura proposes is that multiple functional features borne by a single functional head are permitted to enter into multiple feature checking relations.

Another important proposal of Ura in relation to the idea of multiple feature checking is the ‘Theta-Position Checking’ parameter (&thgr;PC-parameter), which “states that elements can enter into a formal feature-checking relation at their theta-position in a language L only if the value of L's &thgr;PC-parameter is set as [+&thgr;PC]” (Ura 2000: 206). The base structures for transitive and intransitive (unergative) clauses are assumed as follows:

(140)
a. Transitive b. Intransitive (unergative)
(Ura 2000: 206–207, slightly modified)

Let us see how Ura's multiple feature checking works to account for morphological characteristics of ergative languages with [+&thgr;PC]. On the basis of this assumption, DP1 in (140a) enters into a case checking relation with v without moving out of its theta-position, vP-Spec. 28 In this case the case feature [Erg(ative)] is borne by DP1 and v, thus, [Erg] on DP1 is checked off.
Next, through Merge the finite Infl is introduced to (140), as in (141):

DP1 in (141) is closer than DP2 to the target of movement, IP-Spec. However, DP1 has already lost its case feature through ergative case feature checking. DP2 is the only candidate to hold a case checking relation with Infl, so it has to move to IP-Spec. However, DP1 too has to move to a Spec position, it is assumed, to check off the [EPP] feature. Now the extra Spec position (the outer Spec) is utilized as in (142):
The checked case is absolutive in this case. Thus, the logical object (not the subject) enters into the case checking relation with Infl.
In a language with [−&thgr;PC], DP1 must move from its theta-position to a position where its case feature can be checked off; namely, to the Spec of IP.

With this brief outline, let us try to account for the case of split ergatives in Georgian. The case feature checking carried out thus far accounts for morphological case distribution. Recall that Georgian follows the accusative pattern in agreement, according to Marantz (section 6.1.1). This means that agreement in Georgian is based on DP1 in the inner Spec position. As a result, Infl checks off two different features (the EPP feature and the case feature) of two distinct DPs using multiple Spec positions.

To show how this multiple feature checking works with Japanese, the Dative Subject Construction (DSC) is taken up. Sentences with stative psychological predicates and potentials, those with the ni-ga case alignment exemplified in (15) and (16), are analyzed together as the DSC. The subjecthood of DPs marked with ni and the non-subjecthood of nominative objects in the DSC have already been discussed above. Ura states that “this fact indicates that T's nominative case-feature and its &phis;-feature can be checked independently in Japanese and Korean; for, from its morphological manifestation, it is natural to assume that T's nominative case-feature is checked off by the nominative object, and T's &phis;-feature is checked off by the dative subject” (Ura 1999: 231).
Ura's basic assumptions for the analysis of Japanese and Korean case systems are listed below, in order to see the real nature of the whole case checking system as applied to Japanese.

(143) (i) The EPP-feature of T is strong; (ii) the EXPERIENCER (EXP) of the psych-verbs that can occur in the DSC is generated at the Spec of a kind of light verb, which takes a VP with THEME in its complement position; (iii) the light verb in the two-layered VP shell of the psych-verbs that can occur in the DSC may assign a dative case to EXP as an inherent case, and they are allowed not to have an accusative case feature as a lexical idiosyncracy; (iv) agreement may be independent of nominative case; (v) T's phi-feature is strong, but its nominative feature is weak; (vi) T's nominative feature may enter into multiple feature checking relations. 29

With these assumptions, Ura (1999) proceeds to show that the DSC provides supporting evidence for the assumption of multiple feature checking. Sentences (15) and (16b) are typical examples of this construction, whose case alignment, ni-ga, has been discussed in this paper repeatedly in different theoretical frameworks. Ura gives (144b) as the basic structure of sentences like (15), repeated below as (144a):

(144)
a. watasi-tati ni mondai no honsitu ga yoku wakar- u koto
we Dat problem Gen real nature Nom well understand-Pres that
‘that we can understand well the real nature of the problem’
b.
(Ura 1999: (26))

A dative subject, EXP in (144) is merged in the vP-Spec position. The dative marker ni is an inherent case marker, so it does not enter into a case checking relation with anything, even though it is raised to TP-Spec attracted by the strong EPP feature borne by T. Thus, its D feature is checked off in this checking relation. 30 This accounts for its function as subject, in playing the roles of the antecedent of an anaphora, and the trigger of subject orientated honorification and so on. The case feature [Nom] carried by T attracts DP with [Nom], THEME in (144), and enters into the case checking relation with it, checking [Nom] off from the THEME DP. Thus two different features, [EPP] and [Nom], borne by T independently enter into different checking relations with different DPs.

Ura's analysis of the DSC provides evidence for his claim that individual features borne by a single head are checked independently, and that a single feature can check the same feature carried by multiple DPs, as in the case of multiple subjects in Japanese.
Ura continues to demonstrate the derivation of the three case arrays of potentials in this framework with quite a few additional assumptions. The structure posited by Ura (1999) is (145):

In (145) sP stands for the maximal projection of the potential suffix (r)are or (r)e, which bears the [null] case feature, which is to be checked by PRO. This is the same assumption as Watanabe's. Without case absorption, [acc] borne by v is checked off by DP2, and DP1 is raised to TP-Spec to check off its weak nominative case feature at LF. The result is ga-o case alignment. Due to (143iii) the potential suffix optionally assigns ni to DP1 and absorbs the case feature [acc] of v. Now DP1 is raised to TP-Spec attracted by T's strong features, the EPP and phi-features. When [acc] of v is absorbed by the potential affix, DP2 has to move to another TP-Spec position in LF to check off T's nominative case feature. Thus, T enters into feature checking relations with both DP1 and DP2, resulting in ni-ga case alignment. When ni is not assigned to DP1 and case absorption is applied, ga-ga case alignment emerges.

To summarize, case feature checking theories, either Agr-based or not, aim at (i) accounting for the distribution of DPs on case theoretic grounds, (ii) identifying subjecthood of DPs, (iii) motivating NP movement (A movement) in the MP framework, i.e., in the framework without the notion of government, and (iv) accounting for the distribution of PRO, which is tied to the case system.

In terms of (iii) and (iv), the theories taken up in section 6, together with a fairly large number of works currently going on, may be successful, especially in view of their coverage of quite a number of typologically different languages. As for (i) and (ii), there is room to reconsider whether there are other means to achieve these aims, especially concerning (i) languages like Japanese with overt case particles and postpositions invite different approaches to this problem. Kuroda (1988) in section 5.4 and Fukui and Takano (1998) in section 6.5 propose alternatives. Concerning (ii), case checking as a means of identifying subjecthood depends on T(ense), with the case feature [Nom] or [Null]. This means that embedded non-finite clauses must be generated as IP or TP. Kuroda (1988), on the other hand, convincingly argues that Japanese is a language with “non-forced agreement,” and proposes an alternative, which claims that a subject is generated as the external argument of a verb (Ext (V)). Following this proposal, we can account for the subjecthood borne by both matrix and complement subjects. In fact, as has been repeatedly emphasized in sections 5 and 6, the underlying complement subject marked with o in the o-causative and those marked with ni in the ni-causative and the indirect passive have the typical functions of a subject mentioned above. In view of this fact, Kuroda's proposal must be seriously studied together with the function of T(ense) from the point of view of UG.

subsection.heading: 6.5 Fukui and Takano (1998)
subsection.p: Supporting the claim by the MP that linear ordering does not play a role either in LF or in the computation from numeration to LF and that it is part of the phonological component, Fukui and Takano propose the operation of demerge in the phonological component. Demerge recursively applies to the topmost construct formed by Merge and detaches the maximal projection first and starts the concatenation from the first detached element. 31 (See Fukui and Takano (1998) for a formal and detailed presentation of demerge and concatenate.) The result is Specifier-Complement-Head order, namely head final order. The Spec-Head-Comp order in head initial languages is the result of verb raising triggered by the strong feature of the functional head v. The presence or absence of the functional head with the strong feature of attracting a verb to its specifier position accounts for the linear order variation in languages.

According to the above theory, Japanese does not undergo verb raising since its head final order is base generated. As a consequence the standard analysis of accusative case checking based on verb raising is not available for Japanese. 32 This is a desirable consequence in view of the lack of evidence in Japanese for the relevance of the abstract case system. Roughly speaking, Fukui and Takano have come up with a conclusion similar to Kuroda's (1988), that is, in Japanese, subject and object NPs are licensed by ga and o, not by Case checking. The significance of Fukui and Takano's work lies in the account of the process of uninterpretable feature ‘elimination’. The case feature carried by NP and the feature ‘Assign the accusative case’ ([+Acc]) carried by the transitive verb must be eliminated before the derivation terminates in LF, since they are not interpretable. Fukui and Takano claim that “Case particles make case features visible to Spell-Out,” which triggers the elimination of the case feature of an NP because spell-out takes away visible features relevant to the phonological component. Without the case feature, the NP proceeds to LF and the derivation successfully terminates in the covert component, if the other conditions are met. Fukui and Takano further assume that the accusative case in Japanese is an inherent case and that it is linked to a particular theta-role. This means that [+Acc] on the transitive verb can stay on in the covert component as an interpretable feature.

As for the nominative case, it is assumed that T(ense) in Japanese does not carry the case feature ‘Assign the nominative case’. The case particle ga makes the case feature of its complement NP visible, which leads to the elimination of this case feature by spell-out. The case particle ga licenses the multiple subject NP in the same way.

This is a very rough outline of Fukui and Takano's approach to the Japanese case system within the MP framework. This approach seems to be on the right track, but there are some serious problems yet unsolved. One of them is the question of how to account for interrelationships of structural cases and other distributional facts described in sections 4 and 5.

subsection.heading: 7 Conclusion
subsection.p: This summary reveals that the distinction was made between structural and inherent cases already in Kuroda's dissertation (1965), written in the framework of the early generative grammatical model. This distinction has been one of the basic points in Japanese generative grammars up to the present time. However, neither this distinction nor case itself had been included in the main research agenda until the emergence of the ideas of principles and parameters in the early part of the 1980s. Chomsky himself admits, “But as far as I can determine, there was never any distinction made between what we now call structural and inherent Case; I don't know the literature well enough to check, but I asked other people like Giuseppe Longobardi, and apparently there is no clear recognition of the distinction . . . As far as I am aware, this split was not noticed until the P&P approach came along” (Chomsky 2002: 112–113). It is surprising how poorly the results of long and continued efforts of Japanese generativists have fared in the generative tradition.

As was pointed out in the introduction, Japanese traditional linguists did not make the distinction, treating all case particles as markers of noun phrases functioning as predicative modifiers. According to Chomsky, the same applies to research on case in the European tradition. Neither Gruber nor Fillmore made this distinction. Kuroda (1965) achieved an integration of various ideas on case into a well-articulated system.

It is interesting to note that there has emerged a move toward disintegration. Kuroda (1988) is one example, treating the structural o and inherent o together as complements of verbs, structural cases in other words. Inoue (1997a) shows that there is no fast and hard line dividing the structural case particle o and inherent o, using various structural tests. Fukui and Takano admit only the inherent particle o, related to various theta roles. It is hoped that this kind of trend in Japanese linguistics will give some impact on the refinement of the MP, contrary to the fate of the very early efforts to integrate ideas into a claim for the basic distinction among particles.

In the presence of sentences without nominative subjects, as described in Inoue (1998), Ura's assumption that [EPP] is strong in Japanese cannot be maintained. Instead, we have to assume that there are parametric differences among languages in terms of the requirements of sentencehood. Inoue (1998) contends that some languages require the subject–predicate relation, most typically realized as ‘forced agreement’ in Kuroda's terms. Others are satisfied with a topic–comment relation. Still others permit both of them. Japanese falls into the third group, with the subject orientated honorifics and the subject antecedent requirement for anaphora depending on the subject–predicate relation, permitting at the same time the topic–comment relation.

The status of ga is certainly more complex than the nominative case in English. This summary is an attempt to show various approaches to account for its multiple functions. Saito (1982) and Kuroda (1986) are in sharp contrast with respect to the treatment of ga as the subject and focus marker. The former distinguishes them by giving them different syntactic structures, the latter by providing a semantic account for the difference. The multiple subject construction has been approached as well from several theoretical perspectives; Kuno and Kuroda using the subjectivization transformation, Takezawa with the configurational approach utilizing the mechanism of adjunction of a subject to IP, and Ura with the multiple specifier positions for subjects. Finally, the ga marking the object of a stative predicate looks like a default case in Marantz's case realization. All these studies show that the presence or absence of the subject–verb agreement is an important factor in deciding typological differences. In this respect, Kuroda (1988) offers an important perspective for future studies.

subsection.p: All these subsystems are closely tied to each other. With respect to case theory, the abstract Case (nominative and accusative) is assigned to the NPs generated in the positions identified by verbs and verb phrases as theta-positions, that is, theta-role assignable positions. It is further claimed that “a verb with a complement assigns case if and only if it theta-marks its subject” (Chomsky 1986b: 141, (185)). The core of theta-theory is the theta-criterion, which reads as follows: Each argument bears one and only one theta-role, and each theta-role is assigned to one and only one argument (Chomsky 1981: 36). Case theory consists of abstract case assignment to the NPs governed by case assigning heads, Tense and verbs, and the Case filter which requires that every lexical NP must get case assigned to it.
